Coppice Halifax.title: Travelogue Botany [10th Anniversary Retrospective]
Coppice Halifax.about:
In 2014, I was just over halfway through my time in the Botany Bay studio that I'd set up after moving from one point in Columbia to another in 2011, although at that moment in time I had no reason to think we'd ever move again. After years of developing Milieu Music and the work ethic that propelled it in my 10x10 foot Rolling Knoll studio space, Botany Bay's loft studio felt like a much more efficient place from the start. I was still one year out from starting my Deep Earth series, and I was two years into fatherhood, which had changed not only my working hours but my entire creative approach. Following fatherhood was a particularly dark night where I endured my first real panic attack, which was yet another aspect of things in my life that were changing whether I wanted them to or not, putting me on multiple paths of mending, with and without chemical involvement. 



So the music recorded during this time was just as transitional and momentary as everything else surrounding it. Coppice Halifax was nearly ten years deep into my love of elementally influenced sound design, and from April to Autumn of 2014, it doubled as a barometer for my emotional state. The three albums collected here as a set are all celebrating their tenth anniversaries, and through the lens of reappraisal, thinking back to where I was, what was happening around me at that time, they are revealed to have more in common than they do not. 



Chloroformic Forests was a triptych of sessions, released in August, but recorded earlier in the Summer, all devoted to some type of lengthy procedural process, mutating and resampling prior sessions and building new structures out of those. Listening now, I have no idea what they could be rephrasing, and I imagine that this may have been part of the point. Botany Bay, as a space, was more fully devoted to expansive and tangential setups of tape machines, mixers and FX devices, in addition to the usual growing array of synthesizers and drum machines, and unlike Rolling Knoll, which was such a small space that setups had to be broken down and reworked as needed for a given project, Botany Bay allowed these setups to flourish and develop, which led to recordings like these - surrealistic shapes of sound that emerged from pathways that were built for other purposes, revisited and recontextualized. 



Fissured Beach, bearing the prosaic subtitle "Before and After the Long Night," was recorded across two days in March of '14, with the night in between being the aforementioned introduction to the world of panic attacks, which actually landed me in the hospital when it happened. I was shaken by it, because I'd never experienced anything like that before, and it was incidental that this piece of music was able to be started and completed by what I felt were two different versions of myself. Sonically, it follows the same path as Chloroformic - droning passages of amorphous tones and chords that weave in and out of focus, while subtle drum machine rhythms and low bass pulse out a murky dub. 



Cornucopiad was recorded in early Autumn of the year, and closes this set with perhaps the most textural and experimental of the three parts. It was also important to me at the time for having a cover photograph taken by my two-year old daughter Penelope, which I've reproduced as a cover "faceplate" for this 3xCD set, while the photograph on the digital cover is the view from one of two windows in the Botany Bay studio, on a June evening in 2014. 



Altogether, these seven tracks are an accurate look back at Coppice Halifax exactly one decade past, while also paradoxically revealing very little. Coppice Halifax has always been a seasonally affected project, composting rather than composing, building things out of impulse, temperature and reactive sensations, and back then I was doing as much as I possibly could with single live takes in the humid loft. It is, in many ways, music that could only have come from a tired mind and curious hands, in a darkened studio surrounded by woods, somewhere in the Carolinas.
Coppice Halifax.credits:
released September 6, 2024
            
            W/P by Brian Grainger. Recorded at Botany Bay, April-Autumn 2014. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. Text by Brian. Design by ABM&D. Photography for the 3xCD set by Pen LOP. Photography for the digital set by Brian at Botany Bay, June 30 2014. #1-3 originally released as ABX34 (Chloroformic Forests). #4 originally released as ABX28 (Fissured Beach). #5-7 originally released as ABX36 (Cornucopiad). This is Milieu Music number AD73, the 73rd issue in the Arboreal Digest reissue catalog. (C) + (P) Oscillog ASCAP 2024. All nights preserved.

Coppice Halifax.title: Winter Botany [10th Anniversary Retrospective]
Coppice Halifax.about:
Continuing the ongoing line of retrospective reissue sets (following the Raft and River double-album and the Travelogue Botany triptych) is Winter Botany, a look back at two elementally-inspired albums that are both celebrating their tenth anniversaries in 2024. 



The first is Snow Vessel, which is essentially "Ocean Lion in cold weather" in a topical sense, although it also shares a number of characteristics with the Verdant Acre sessions and various moments in the Static Pharming series. It consists of three side-long (vinyl sides, that is) tracks that were all drafted live during an unexpectedly snowed-in day in February of '14. Snow was, as one might imagine, extremely uncommon in the subtropics, but it does occasionally happen, and when it does, everything shuts down, because South Carolina is completely unequipped to deal with that type of climate. So I spent the whole day in my loft studio, which remained warm whether there was snow on the ground or not, and surfed the soundwaves with my Lowrey organ on pedal bass, a couple drum machines (Korg ER-1, Boss DR-880) and a swirling mass of tape loops, synth washes and treated field recordings. 



The second album offered in this set is Ice Forest, originally issued at Recycled Plastics as #31 in the Bedroom Compost series. This two-session pair came to be in November of '14, just as the temperatures began to drop again in Columbia, and they were built deliberately in what was already in 2014 considered the "early style" of Coppice Halifax music, which is to say extremely textural compressor abuse combined with deep bass forms and tape processing. If memory serves correctly, these two pieces were part of a wider set of sessions that eventually produced the Urceolatmospherion album, which was recorded the following year in 2015, but sat unreleased in development hell until late 2016 at ROHS. The "Melted" version was held off of the digital release at Recycled Plastics, available only as a CD-R exclusive track, so many people today may find this cut is new to them. 



Both albums were recorded some time apart, but despite this, were meant to keep me warm on cold weather days, and they were both created using mostly the same gear in the same Botany Bay studio space. For these reasons, they've been linked in my mind's eye ever since and pairing them together on this double-album retrospective feels like completing the circle to some degree. As with all of the CH reissue sets from 2024, Winter Botany has been offered at a "nice price" with a limited 2xCD-R reissue set that includes the original photograph from Snow Vessel, set against textured white cardstock inserts with fresh new sticker and disc face designs.
Coppice Halifax.credits:

Coppice Halifax.title: Earthworks Compleat
Coppice Halifax.about:
2025 EDITOR'S NOTES: 



It has now been a full decade since I released the two-volume "Earthworks" album, in September and October of the 2015 year. At the time, the albums felt like a notable high point in the Halifaxian landscape, which were very much a post-"Verdant Acre" work, although looking back now, with a different perspective, they feel utterly alien and distant, even a little incomprehensible to me. 2015 was the last full year of my life I would spend in South Carolina, and by the time these albums were published, although I did not yet know it, I would be relocated to Ohio less than twelve months later. When I left the deep south, I was so content with my decision, determined to never look back, ready to leave the Green Hell once and for always, so reappraising work like this, which to me feels so completely Carolinian in its dense humidity and overgrown process, feels more like rediscovering a past life, and in many ways, it really is. Before moving to Ohio, the way Coppice Halifax albums were recorded was so totally different - machines and cables sprawled all over the carpet of a stiflingly hot loft studio, the lights off, everything illuminated only by what could come through the two windows and emanate from the machines themselves - and after relocating and really having a tabula rasa to create a newer and more well-organized studio space with all of this hardware, the entire process changed, and slowly gave way to my current working methods with modular systems. And from this vantage point, now, I look back at "Earthworks" and feel like I am standing in field of stone ruins, wondering what structure once stood and whose hands built it, unambiguously certain that it could not have been me. 



ORIGINAL 2015 COPY: 



After being invited to the 2015 edition of Cold Fiction's ongoing Futur[e]cho, I began a session with a few drum machines, a heap of FX boxes and a two-minute long reel-to-reel tape loop of a calmer horn refrain from Smetana's classic "Mà Vlast (My Homeland)". In short, a similar setup as the Verdant Acre excursions, though much different by the time I finished.



In my usual fashion of aural degradation and textural processing, I treated the tape loop heavily with all sorts of eroding and elongating, however no matter what I applied to the loop, the end result would sound beautiful. This became a challenge - overdoing the compression, smearing flange and phasing and detuned chorus everywhere, almost acting recklessly, abusing the tape and testing the strength of the foundation Smetana established in 1879. No matter what I tried, the music defiantly shined that much brighter, resilient beneath the analog loss, poignantly echoing across time the stately horns of the past. 



Once I realized this fact, the sessions settled into a calm relationship of understanding and love. A soft conversation with an old friend. My choice of the name for the session, before even starting it - Redoubt - along with the source of my tape loop, came into focus as a subconscious celebration of contentment at home. I peppered the tracks with field recordings of my daughter playing with my wife and I in our verdant backyard. I imagined the redoubts in my mind not as fortresses built for military defense, but as safe havens, well worn from warm sun and embracing winds, built to stand up to the ravages of time and gravity by craftsmen long since forgotten.

Coppice Halifax.title: Solus Compleat
Coppice Halifax.about:
Collected here for the tenth anniversary of the first album, "Solus" is now reinstated with all three iterations of the piece and no less than eighteen different variations spread across three discs of runtime, offering a massive six-disc listening experience. 



"Solus" was meant as an experimental approach to many of my different interests within Coppice Halifax in 2014, with a deep focus on textural events, by way of incidental or environmental sounds, organic contours shaped by filtering and lossy recording processes, and the deliberate introduction of different types of noise into rhythmic frameworks. The initial idea was always to create something that was predominantly a rhythmic structure - usually a kick drum or kick-drum-like pulse with or without some percussive elements - with the entirety of the tonal/melodic content of the music being mixed very far below the rhythm, burying it under the noise floor. With this, the listener would be able to play "Solus" in an open-air environment, preferably with the sounds of that environment present enough to fill in the spaces left in the music, with the deep backdrop of tonal sound merely meant as a coloration rather than something that would compete for the listener's attention. 



Whether or not anyone ever listened to "Solus" in this way, besides myself, I have never found out, nor does it really matter at all. Even now, I am not entirely sure that I was able to accomplish what I set out to do in these three attempts. This is almost always the mystifying reality of revisiting work from a decade past - the original intent becomes fuzzy, rewritten, and the current perspective changes how I even interact with things I've made, whether I remember making them or not. Regardless, I enjoy how obtuse many of these recordings still are today, and they align well with my "keep techno weird" ethos a decade later. 



The eighteen subtitled mixes that appear here are, appropriately, exercises in the inverse direction of the main three pieces. That is to say, sections of "Solus" in all three iterations have been re-sampled, zoomed in upon microscopically and forced into more "present" mixes, with the noise and the subtleties now at the forefront, further transfigured by additional hardware and software processing into these orbiting planetoids that each seem to carry their own physical laws and transient logics. A fair few of them are quite heavy, and would probably feel like a woolly mammoth stomping through the club if they were ever brought to a dancefloor. 



While the "Solus" material has never been at the forefront of either my own creative interests or the commercial viability of my work through the listeners' views, it remains unique enough as a self-contained experiment that somewhat connects the humidity-soaked CH albums that led to it with the peripheral zones and outliers of Deep Earth sessions yet to come. By my current standards of mixing and mastering, I have a hard time thinking that much of this music would be issued in this state today, but this is also what makes it interesting to revisit, and worth preserving without attempting to "clean it up" for purposes it was never designed to attend. Having also been less than completely satisfied with the presentation of all six albums, in both their digital and physical editions - likely due to the inherent "otherness" of the music itself - I am now pleased to collect all of this music and issue it somewhat definitively in a coherent and singular state.

Coppice Halifax.title: Mountain Interval
Coppice Halifax.about:
"Mountain Interval" is the newest Coppice Halifax full-length effort in the field of melodious and rhythmic electronic music - be that house, dub, one of dozens of variations of techno, or whatever other record-shop-bin label you'd need to use to describe it for the layman. It is music composed with computers, drum machines, synthesizers and a wide array of processors in the modular and hardware/software worlds. These nine tracks pick up directly where things like "River Mural" and "Transient Logics" have signed off, offering once again an album that, in one moment, will sound like a Halifaxian acre, and in the next, may recall another scenic overlook from a Milieu recording. 



In that sense, "Mountain Interval" is very much about the oscillation that lies at the heart of all things - up/down, on/off, left/right, yes/no, open/closed, zero and one - and in my usual way of working, I like to further explore those oscillations in more prosaic ways - positive and negative, here to there, happy and sad, new and old, fast and slow, Summers and Winters, Autumns and Springs. The sinewave that moves time from point to point and space from hill to valley and back again. Coppice Halifax has always been an elementally driven project, named in equal halves of seven letters each for the land and the sea, which is apt here too. Leaving home, and coming back again - the transient logic that brings us to tomorrow, and allows us to reduce the present moment to something behind us. 



You will find, I hope, all of those things and more in these colorful soundwaves, in music that I made initially in a stoned and impulsive environment, chasing joy and endorphin release without looking at the clock or thinking about an album, a product, a job or anything else that our current era tells us should be our focus. When I first went to bed with the fruits of that first session, these tracks were only loops of simple drums/bass/chords, a little delay trail panning them around, nothing more. I enjoyed those versions enough that I was tempted to just release them as they were, always wanting to make my contribution to the great canon of electronic minimalism alongside the masters like Modell, Hitchell, Voigt, James and so many others that have been coloring my headphones and bedrooms for many years now. 



But that wouldn't have been "Mountain Interval" - not really. The work that sits before you now had to be excavated from under, behind and between those loops, and in some cases, when I had dug too deep beneath the foundations I laid, I had to supplement, augment and amalgamate with new structures. Somewhere in there, the usual conversations happened - what to add, what to remove, and when - and like all good dub albums, "Interval" passed through around a dozen different iterations, some additive, some subtractive, some simply re-colored or tinted with contrast tools, some rearranged like the modular system that bore them. 



All of this is the fun part, the chasing of glimpses, the optimism of wandering across the landscape, forever curious about what lies on the other side of the hill, hopeful that it is something new, but somehow still comforted when it is not, and in between those places, a moment at the top, closer to the clouds, like the crest of a wave that can hold us for as long as we want it to, while we look further out than before, and see all the other intervals moving around us - day to night, beginning to end - realizing when we finally begin to clamber down the path ahead that they have both always been there, a perfectly symmetrical superposition, a harmony of life to a lovely tune, as Brooks Bowman once beautifully wrote in 1934. 



I hope you'll let me carry you through these nine colorful bends again, as I myself have worn down their footpaths as I lost myself in their tangles for the last year. At a time when life is not nearly as imitative of art as we'd like it to be, I flee into the latter, and to date, it has never failed to make up the difference that I need it to make.

Coppice Halifax.title: Whitehope Compleat
Coppice Halifax.about:
"Whitehope" celebrates its tenth anniversary in 2024, prompting me to revisit it, reevaluate it and, as you can now see, reissue it. "Whitehope" was a very special recording at the time, something that I'd been trying to find for years, and always losing my way, ending up somewhere else, resulting in releases such as "Narcotic Months" and others that don't come immediately to mind. It was more than an idea, it was also a texture, a feeling, as close to a physical fabric as an imagined location could ever be, but saturated by a deep sensation that you had already been there before, that it wasn't a dream but a memory, a possible past. 



I chased this vision with many different machines, in different waking and drinking and sleep-deprived states, and only after giving up and moving on, resigned to the conclusion that I'd never reach this fantasia that felt so tangible to my mind's eye, did I listen back to a session during the Summer of '14 and, there surrounding me in my headphones like a cloud, was "Whitehope." In all my creative meandering, from the joy of exploring sound simply for the sake of doing so, "Whitehope" emerged on the horizon line, and I captured it without even realizing it, feeling later a surreal sensation that the universe had played a trick on me, drugged me enough to divulge my deepest desires without being aware I was doing so. 



When it occurred to me that "Whitehope" was there on the tape machine, it was one of the few times in those earlier years that I felt as if the music was being found, rather than made - specific examples being the port wine-stained sessions for "Beyond the Sea/Stars" and the first "Ocean Lion" album - that it was someone else who had discovered it, and I was now merely a passenger on a trip that gave me deja vu. This feeling became more proliferated later on, as I found ways to give up more and more of my ego and conscious brain to impulses and reactive changes, navigating the sound by vibration in the dark room for Deep Earth sessions a year later, and beyond that, subtracting myself entirely from the proceedings with my ever-growing modular system, which today carries me like a cozy vessel through the same soundwaves that I must have found the shores of "Whitehope" within. 



So, looking back on these pieces now, I don't know that I feel those sensations quite like they came upon me before. I still feel very disconnected from them, as if I am an interloper in a vibrant landscape that no one has seen in many years, or perhaps ever, and perhaps that is more than enough of a legacy for something that I had dreamt about for so long, and apparently willed to exist subconsciously. Offered here are six discs of recordings, all made from the point of the titular session onward, all exploring every curvature of the composition and growing new botanicals from the compost.



The opening track and the three-part variations following it exist in a state of superposition - both are "Whitehope," even though the canonical main affair is the 60+ minute work - as the tripartite mixes manifested during the same session. Following these two albums are the four subsequent mixes of "Whitehope" from the "Sublimated Ivorine Reagents" album, along with the sole live performance of "Whitehope" at the Conundrum Music Hall in Columbia, South Carolina in the end of 2014, which was attended by a handful of people who probably looked on in confusion as I coaxed these sounds from a Tascam tape machine, two drum machines and some FX devices. 



Disc four is the "Imperial Grey" album, originally issued for free at my friend Matias' Temiong Recordings imprint (home of the great Ayqix), which consists of seven variations that were recorded during rehearsals for the CMH performance. Closing the set on discs five and six are the "Winterhope" album - two extended ambient pieces pulled directly from the cassette in the Tascam tape machine that was the core of the CMH live set, retrieved later when I found the tape after thinking it was lost. 



Everything is offered here as it was, with no additional mastering work or changes, as my desire to see the past as it is, rather than through the sea-sprayed glasses of nostalgia, is more important with such elemental and exploratory recordings as these. As with all of my recent reissues, "Whitehope Compleat" is being offered in a budget set of 6xCD-Rs in a clear plastic bag, with a "nice price" for both the digital and physical iterations. Whitehope, for being ten years old, sounds more like ten-thousand, hearing the tape-hiss winds and waves against the smoothed over sand and stone of the coastline. I hope it carries you as long and as far as it has carried me.

Coppice Halifax.title: The Mosaic Wind
Coppice Halifax.about:
The second pre-album release single for/from "Mountain Interval," forthcoming in mid-March (either Detroit Day or Pi Day), is "The Mosaic Wind" - a more danceable and vibrant work that follows the dub of "Blue Air" with a colorful look forward to Spring.



The title track is a bit of post-"Watch the Head" bass work (Korg Poly 800, Oberheim SEM/OB-X, Waldorf PPG) alongside a psychedelic landscape of modular house chords and meticulously processed drum machines like the Yamaha MR-10 and RX11. Lots of wide stereo movement, and some intricate FM sequencing through the end.



The second cut is an effervescent remix of the forthcoming album's title track by Zwei Kreise, who transfigures a palette of only Halifaxian loops into a sprawling and electric structure that recalls old favorites like Phonem or Musik Aus Strom, but retains the distinct melodic personality of his many previous mixes for me, familiar and alien all at once, with large areas of free fall between the two. 



A palette cleanser of beatless Roland Juno 106 through some lush Airwindows and Arturia processors follows, re-coloring the air. Then an "Interval" outtake that explores Oberheim machines for its bass and lead parts over upbeat dance rhythms from Roland TR-505, Korg ER-1 and 8-bit drum machines. The whole set closes with a gassed acre of vapor, a twelve-minute train line through Voigt and Dettinger shaped forestry that eventually dissipates into an early morning pointillist dew - "In an Ink Black Sky" was originally the closing piece for "Mountain Interval" before being replaced with a very different cut, but here it still pulls down the curtain perhaps more effectively following the rest of the tracks.



Limited CD-R editions are available for both "The Mosaic Wind" and the first single "Blue Air," both of them in matching white jackets with circular matte cover stickers of Holga photographs from 2008 around my old Rolling Knoll studio.

Coppice Halifax.title: Blue Air
Coppice Halifax.about:
"Blue Air" is a single for/from the forthcoming Coppice Halifax album Mountain Interval, containing one LP track and four outtakes/alternative mixes as b-sides, all of which were excised from Mountain Interval for runtime limitations only. In this way, the "Blue Air" single isn't really a single at all, so much as a sibling to the main album being utilized in a more surface-level promotional capacity. 



The music offered here happened, for the most part, incidentally. All of it, save for two tracks, stemming from a single illuminating session with my third variant of the invaluable Ornament and Crime multipurpose module in my Audioholistics modular system. This third version of Ornament differs from the first two I possess, bearing a much more powerful processor that transforms the machine from more of a voltage and clock utility into a four-channel synthesizer/drum machine/effects processing workstation, sort of like half of my beloved Yamaha QY-70, in Eurorack format. From nothing more than preliminary testing of this machine came an entirely unexpected album of work, and although I should not be surprised when this happens, twenty years into my creative process, it nonetheless always comes on like a strange lucid moment, as if I was away from my body while the work happened, and returned just in time to hear it emanating from my speakers. 



Once the core idea of the album was in hand, it only needed to be finished by way of careful editing and augmentation. Overdub and arrangement sessions followed, using a wealth of virtual and physical machines that each occupy a distinct space in my studio, making the music you hear something that could only exist in the here and now of Coppice Halifax. This stands in contrast to the recent Shades of Night in Green Minor album, which mostly existed several years in the past before being brought to the surface. "Blue Air" and Mountain Interval are instead the shape of Coppice Halifax music today. 



To be sure, many of my dearest influences from the world of rhythmic and psychedelic electronic music loom large over these pieces - Rod Modell, Stephen Hitchell, Stefan Betke, Wolfgang Voigt, Hiroshi Yoshimura, Thomas Brinkmann, Terre Thaemlitz, Erik Kowalski, Olaf Dettinger, Richard D. James, just to name a handful who all cast shadows over the way my music comes to life. Without their stellar contributions to the public consciousness, I don't really think this music would exist. Further, my friend, mentor and all-around guru David Burraston deserves individual thanking here, as it has been at his encouragement alone that I have delved into so many of these specific machines and their processes. 



It is my sincere hope that "Blue Air" and the subsequent Mountain Interval album satisfy those who feel that Coppice Halifax has remained a bit more withdrawn over the last two years. I myself have felt that way about it, unsure of how or why it happened. I've just chalked it up to Milieu's extensive work with procedural ambient forms and the absolutely exhaustive gauntlet of making Watch the Head, but as always, it could simply be that Coppice Halifax music needed to disappear only so it could return, as Wolfgang Voigt once wisely stated.

Coppice Halifax.title: Pink Acre Plastic Acre
Coppice Halifax.about:
"Nestled in bedroom warmth and backyard field recordings, filled with echoing moments of adventuring with my daughter, Pink Plastic bounds through green grass and crashes into honeysuckles, before curling up on a worn out sofa for a nap in a sunbeam. Miniature soundtracks for roaming, dreaming, bouncing and brainstorming." 



Two limited cassette tapes of bubbly ambient techno, originally issued at Recycled Plastics in 2017, and briefly reinstated in an equally limited 2xCD-R set, are now finally being made available again with a "nice price" double-disc set in lighter and more shipping-efficient packaging. "Pink Acre" and "Plastic Acre" were both a conscious follow-up to "Milkwhite Plastic Galaxy Maker," and as such, this reissue has been designed to match the latter's current reissue edition as well, making it more evident than it's ever been that the recordings are meant to coexist alongside one another.  coppicehalifax.bandcamp.com/album/milkwhite-plastic-galaxy-maker-expanded-reissue

Coppice Halifax.title: Transient Logics
Coppice Halifax.about:
Transient Logics was privately commissioned by David Hamlin in 2022, and came into existence slowly over a year of session work, with this album being not the first, or second, but third iteration of the on-paper ideas that defined it. Recorded following the exhaustive gauntlet of Milieu's Watch the Head album, Transient Logics manages to embody a sort of Halifaxian version of Head, exploring many of Head's compositional ideas (such as prolific use of odd-metered polymetric patterns) as well as its sound-palette (lots of wavetable, FM and Karplus-Strong synthesis). 



Like the denser and more varied compositions on Watch the Head, Transient Logics goes through several different rhythmic structures and melodic phases, which overlap with one another in different ways as the track's hour-long runtime passes by - if you listen carefully, a bassline from one section may return later in another section, unchanged, and yet utterly new when placed over a different rhythmic time division. The points of emphasis change over time too, with the first and third beats of a piece of melodic information sometimes mutating into the second and fourth beats, while many patterns forsake the "standard" four/eight/sixteen step conventions entirely. The rhythmic elements use a lot of heavy DJ-style processing, with high and low-pass filters being employed alongside pans and fades to allow a more hypnotic and seamless pulse, with several "now you hear it now you don't" moments coming and going beneath the overlapping chords, bass and lead melodic parts. 



Earlier in the process, Transient Logics began life as a session of Buchla 200 system ambient music, with the only remnants of this original provenance appearing in the first section of this recording. The Buchla sessions were developed fully into an album all their own during this time, and they will be released within the calendar year as the Forest Idyl four-disc album under the Milieu name. 



Once the sessions that became Forest Idyl indicated that they were only a seed of what was yet to come, the first iteration of Transient Logics (and the second phase of the overall project) began to form, again as several lengthy ambient pieces, spread across a monolithic five disc span, consisting of all the melodic elements you hear within this CH recording, presented from a completely different perspective. These recordings will also see a separate release later in the year, as I feel they are more suited to Autumn than Summer, although trainspotters will note a special 2xCD-R edition of Transient Logics offered here, which contains three of these Milieu recordings on a second disc, issued ahead of the full set. 



Altogether, when I finally turned in the work to David Hamlin, it was ten discs of material, all bound up within this complex process. David was a gracious patron, and joined me in the last phase of the process to give these recordings a visual body. He generously gave me two photographs (which I modified in collaboration with him for the CH and Milieu versions of Transient Logics) and a relief print he created in 2023 for the Forest Idyl album cover. The photographs depict a nearly Brutalist landscape of city buildings, which David constructed from physical pieces of textile material he'd assembled in his own studio. I've tinted the photographs green and blue hues that I've swatched from the ARP Odyssey - one of my all-time favorite analog synthesizers in terms of both sound and design, which also appears on this album. 



Transient Logics is not the first or the last addition to the growing body of work that blurs the lines between Milieu and Coppice Halifax, a practice that was canonized with 2018's Sun Cast, although several examples of this were published prior to that moment. It is joined by albums like Pawleys Island, River Mural and Milkwhite Plastic Galaxy Maker, even the recent Shades of Night in Green Minor, with its ability to inhabit multiple acres of my creative estate, often at the same moment. This is why, although it may be confusing for listeners, you will see a Coppice Halifax album called Transient Logics, and a Milieu album called Transient Logics. They are both the same composition, the same audio-matter and vibrational arrangement of molecules, simply experienced from two very different perspectives. Neither is the true work, both are variations. It makes me wonder how many more Transient Logics peripherally exist, further out, past the horizon line we can see from here. 



Transient Logics is, in this sense, a commentary on my position as an artist - surrounded by my tools, influenced constantly by the ebb of time, the change of seasons, the poison of nostalgia - I am always on my way from somewhere, and proceeding to another destination. Never able to outrun my own shadow, always instead becoming the momentary window through which I can see where I have been.

Coppice Halifax.title: The Invisible Subcontinent
Coppice Halifax.about:
Throughout the almost twenty years of Coppice Halifax recordings, a number of patterns have emerged again and again, sometimes without my awareness of this happening until well after the fact. The Invisible Continent collects twelve sessions I initially recorded across all twelve months of 2021, privately released to the subscribers of the Deep Earth series as they came to pass. 



Usually, my preference is to keep such material exclusive to the series,where it originated, but these twelve EPs continually resurfaced in my mind, until I realized somewhere along the line that this was a coherent set of deep techno music that absolutely follows the lineage of things like Static Pharming and Astral Salons. 



So it was decided to make an exception to my usual rule, and release this set as its own series, which is what you see here. I think anyone who enjoyed Static Pharming or Astral Salons will find a lot to explore here, and I encourage listeners to consider these twelve EPs as a sort of ghostly sibling to those runs. A surrealistic echo, returning years after the original signal has vanished.



The full set has been made available for a "nice price" of only $22 for the digital series, although individual EPs may be purchased for $5.55 each. Additionally, a very limited physical edition is on offer, with four separate discs in stickered sleeves, similar to the Leaf Cloak reissue set from earlier this year.

This material appears courtesy of Distrans Telekomm, and has been reproduced with their permission. This is Milieu Music number DE-C6B. (C) + (P) Oscillog ASCAP 2024. All nights preserved.

Coppice Halifax.title: Raft and River [Tenth Anniversary Compleat]
Coppice Halifax.about:
'Raft and River' collects two Coppice Halifax albums that were recorded and released in 2014 - 'Raft' (ABX30) and 'River Tableaux' (ABX31) - and reinstates them as a double-album for their shared tenth anniversaries. Both of these albums were built in the exact same way, using the same studio tools and methodology, and both came into being as a sort of 'expanded single' for compilation tracks that were originally issued at Cold Fiction. 



Reassembled and revisited here, 'Raft and River' feel like more of a designed pair than they might not, expressing many of my interests in textured analog-driven electronic music and minimal dub music at that point in time. They feel warm and humid, very much a part of the sweltering subtropical climes they originated from, and perhaps could even be considered as supplemental works to more important 2014 sessions such as 'Whitehope' or the second leg of 'Static Pharming' that was running concurrently from month to month that year. 



'Raft and River' have been reinstated, but not remastered, as I am beginning to feel that my work from a decade prior has finally hit some kind of a plateau point, where I am either content to leave it as it is, as a time capsule, or I already feel the material is sufficiently mixed and mastered. Both albums have been out of print for years, and this tenth anniversary reissue aims to recirculate the recordings with newer cover photography (for the digital version) and a reduced "nice price," alongside a limited 2xCD-R edition that includes both of the original photographic covers for 'Raft' and 'River Tableaux.' Gratitude is owed to James at Cold Fiction for inviting me, again and again, to contribute work to his label, and in so doing, for facilitating the creation of these albums.
Coppice Halifax.credits:

This edition's cover photo taken in Cleveland, OH in 2017. Cover photographs for 'Raft' and 'River Tableaux' taken in Columbia, SC in 2013 at Sesquicentennial State Park. This is Milieu Music number AD67, 67th in the Arboreal Digest reissue catalog. (C) + (P) Oscillog ASCAP 2024. All nights preserved.

Coppice Halifax.title: Leaf Cloak [Tenth Anniversary Compleat]
Coppice Halifax.about:
It was 2013, and my sweltering Botany Bay loft studio was two years running, with the previous year an exhausting blur of time as I became a father for the first time. A lot of things were in a continual sense of freefall, with occasional tugs of forward motion, and having completed what I set out to do within the electronic dub/ambient techno template with the Analog Botany series and 'Pawleys Island,' there was a tangible desire to reapproach that sound and palette from within this newer and more developed studio. 



By comparison, my 10x10 room at Rolling Knoll was more a guest bedroom I'd taken root in and filled with a disorganized array of hardware, instruments and label operation materials - Botany Bay represented the first time I'd moved into a space with the word "studio" in my mind as we worked out how many rooms were needed, and what they might be for. While it would still be a couple years before I'd amassed enough esoteric hardware to begin the Deep Earth series, Botany Bay was a distinctly different creative world to work inside, having already given me the Verdant Acre series the previous year, as well as a host of other textured deep techno excursions like 'Reflector,' 'Coastal Reveries,' my 'Dilate/Erode' split with Submersion and the hallucinogenic 'Narcotic Months.'



'Leaf Cloak' was in many ways the summation of all of those recordings, informed by late nights running on fumes, at times staying up working until dawn, finding the Analog Botany sound beneath a tangle of tape crust, white noise haze and the usual crumbling overdriven compressor. If 'Pawleys Island' was Coppice Halifax combing the seaside and driving alone through rural backroads, 'Leaf Cloak' is a paean to a humid green backyard behind a studio, a totemic symbol of a new life and new paths being continually explored, having left the beach and the backroads behind for good. 



So, collected here are all of the original recordings made for 'Leaf Cloak' and its orbiting moons** - the burnt out rehash of 'Chemist Cloak' and the almost industrial dub 'Night Soil' - as well as three alternate mixes plucked from the 'Sleeping Under Furs' versions-collection, and the 'Blue Cloak' revisitation album drafted earlier this year for this occasion. You will hear a distinct palette of sounds, all coalescing in a gradient that shifts between moments that are either more naturalistic and overgrown, or more machine directed and dubbed. All of it is bathed in the warm noise of my Columbia home, the inescapable permanent Summer of the subtropics, which is all very far away from me as I write this now, a decade later. 



For my part in this reissue in 2023, I wanted to approach the material with a careful and conservative hand, since I've always enjoyed the mixing and the texture present on these albums, and wanted to preserve those things, while also going down the usual checklist of equalization fixes, standard cleanup work from the vantage point of a decade of doing this. It is for this reason that 'Leaf Cloak' is not being reissued as having been remastered, but rather, 'optimized' would be a good way to put it. 



However, both 'Chemist Cloak' and 'Night Soil' have benefited from a more involved mastering pass, being wild and unruly recordings made at a chaotic time in my life, when work was perhaps going out the door with a bit less scrutiny than as was my usual. 'Chemist Cloak' is the most noticeable in this regard, and it is worth noting that I could only clean these recordings up so well due to the Great Drive Crash of 2015 wiping my master session files from existence. Your mileage may vary here. 



In any case, I am beyond happy to have all of these recordings unified and arranged in such an organized fashion, and I hope that this collection makes it easier to discover these recordings for newcomers who weren't with me yet in '13. Here's to another ten years of 'Leaf Cloak' in your stereo systems and headphones.



**For the trainspotters and completionists, I will note here that I have omitted all of the remixes produced by other musicians, out of respect for both their work and these original pieces. Those recordings (the 'Ash Cloak' album, as well as some stray mixes on 'Night Soil') are all still available digitally in their original forms, should you wish to investigate them, but for sake of a coherent whole, they do not appear here.

Coppice Halifax.title: Sunworn
Coppice Halifax.about:
'Sunworn' was a session recorded in Autumn of 2019, undertaken for the Adventurous Music imprint in Leipzig, for their multimedia release 'Relatives Schoensein' that paired a 92-page book of photographs by Signalstoerung with a compilation of original music. The book and compilation were issued in July of the following year, and (as of this writing) a few copies of the book are still available here:  adventurousmusic.bandcamp.com/album/relatives-schoensein



 The label was sent the entire eight-track session to choose the compilation track from, and what is presented here as (Mix 2.2) was mastered and released on 'Relatives Schoensein' and labeled on the release as 'Sunworn.' Until now, the full session in its original mastered form has remained unreleased, and feels apt to publish in the midst of the Summer heat three years later. 'Sunworn' is a two-hour runtime laid across two discs, and beautifully transmuted into visual compost with a new cover by the inimitable Eric Adrian Lee. 



Musically, the session emanated from multiple sampler devices - the Volca Sample, KP-2 and ES-1 from Korg, a Boss RC-20 looper, an Akai S2800 - alongside several analog and digital hardware synthesizers, such as Roland's SH-32, a Korg Minilogue and Monologue, and a Boss DS-330 Dr. Synth. Copious amounts of signal processing were used, such as staples like the Alesis Quadraverb, BBE Two Timer delay and Pioneer SR202W spring reverb box, but also more esoteric processors like the Soundblox Tri-Mod phaser, an Ibanez Synth-Wah and PM7 Phase Modulator. The session was recorded in eight live takes with the Peavey FX2 and Mackie ProFX8 mixers, recorded into a Tascam DP008EX and mastered in Goldwave. 



Although 'Sunworn' is already three years old, it is filled with a number of textures and sequencing ideas that I am still today exploring, such as a prolific amount of odd metered pattern work, twelve-bit sampling and deliberately lossy recording formats employed for their instability and textural uniqueness, as well as a number of spatial and feedback-oriented approaches that hopefully conjure up visions of sweltering Summer heat, teary-eyed sunshine and wavering vapors coming off the surface of the asphalt.
Coppice Halifax.credits:

Mix 2.2 previously released at Adventurous Music, 2020, in a different master from those included here. Text by Brian. Design by Eric Adrian Lee. This is Milieu Music number ABX119. (C) + (P) Oscillog ASCAP 2023. All nights preserved. Special thanks to Ro and Eric for their generosity and continual support of my work.

Coppice Halifax.title: Milkwhite Plastic Galaxy Maker [Expanded Reissue]
Coppice Halifax.about:
I'd originally wanted to do something to celebrate "Milkwhite" in 2022, for the tenth anniversary of the album, but 2022 was a big year, full of flowers that disappear, among many other things, and it just slipped past. So, for the 12th anniversary of "Milkwhite" instead, I am pleased to reinstate the album alongside its original expanded single/sister album "Sno Dreem" in a comprehensive double-disc set. Further, this 2xCD-R set follows reissues of "Pawleys Island" and "River and Raft" with a "nice price" of reduced cost and a lighter, more shipping-friendly packaging design, keeping the music available and affordable - two things that a lot of music is not, these days. 



"Milkwhite" has always held a special place in my mind, perhaps because it is one of those CH recordings that manages to effortlessly balance itself between the CH and Milieu melodic worlds, but also, because it was made almost entirely free of pretense. Every track presented here was recorded exclusively for the purpose of listening to while I read specific paperbacks in bed at night, as I would often have a hard time finding the right sort of music to accompany my reading, and ended up making a number of different recordings to "score" the material with. 



"Milkwhite" is also notable for the presence of a number of specific drum machines and synthesizers, which by the time I'd completed "Milkwhite" in 2012, I'd managed to build up enough of to realize albums like this one. You can hear my deep explorations of Korg's ER-1 drum synthesizer and Roland's SH-32 polysynth, as well as the Boss DR-660 and DR-880 machines I'd inherited from Obfusc and David Tagg, respectively. These units sit gracefully alongside other staples, such as the Lowrey "Magic Genie" organ and my Tascam four-track tape machine, and the resampled cheap Casio keyboard that was used all over "Bedroom Carpet" also makes quite a few appearances here too.

Coppice Halifax.title: Cmx [Volumes VIII-XV]
Coppice Halifax.about:
The Cmx series exists to compile and arrange volumes of Coppice Halifax remix commissions, each album paired with a rarity of some kind - a compilation track, an alternative mix, an outtake - and the series has continued in this fashion since the first volume was released in 2008. Over ten years later, the current number of volumes is fifteen, which I felt necessitated a second retrospective box set, following the first collection that combined volumes one to seven across eight discs of audio. This second collection combines volumes eight to fifteen, again across eight discs, and for the occasion, a reissue of the first box set has been arranged to coincide with this new one. 



Altogether, it's surreal to me, to look back and see the fruits of my labor, having worked with audio from so many fantastic producers, many of whom I had admired long before I was invited to remix their music. Of the forty-three tracks offered here, there are melodious braindance and ambient techno cuts, deep dub techno excursions, minimalistic ambient drifts and all shades of experimental electronic music. Volume ten is even a 70+ minute DJ set that was made to coincide with the tenth anniversary of Coppice Halifax itself, featuring many of my favorite remixes at that point in time. Just about every style I've explored on a CH album is represented here in some form, making the listening experience a consistent but varied one, a trip that I hope you'll enjoy taking as much as I have.
Coppice Halifax.credits:

Text and design by ABM&D. This is Milieu Music number ABX131. (C) + (P) Coppice Halifax & the credited artists 2023. All nights preserved.

Coppice Halifax.title: Cmx XV
Coppice Halifax.about:
The fifteenth volume of Coppice Halifax remix commissions has arrived, bringing with it fifty-two minutes of analog botany across five tracks.



Opening the proceedings this time is a previously unreleased cut called 'Masted Arc' that was initially recorded in 2018, and final-glossed in 2023. It originated as a jam built using the Cedar Mast samples (from the Sega Dreamcast) alongside a Korg KPR-77 drum machine from 1983, but was finished using a myriad of different devices, such as the Boss DR-110 and Yamaha MR-10 drum machines, alongside several digital synthesizers and FX boxes. 



From there, a hidden bonus track from Adrien75's 2018 'Is Still Alive' album injects a subtropical sleaze into the album, with the Beach Fuzz mix of 'Hawaiian Ring Drum Rum.' This cut recalls Halifaxian recordings like High Hawaiian Fog and Coastal Reveries, while also nodding to classic Adrien75 records like 'Coastal Acces' and the 757 LP. 



Continuing the tidal pull to the horizon line is the CH version of 'One Thousand Dances' from Magic Arrows' absolutely essential album Sweet Heavenly Angel of Death. I was graciously invited to remaster the expanded reissue of the album in the Summer of 2019, and Mr. Arrows preferred that I do a new mix of 'One Thousand Dances' in order to replace the original mix on the reissue. I protested at the time, as I have long felt that Angel of Death was and is a perfect album, but all the same, no one knows what they want more than the artist, and so this mix came to be. It was built, as all CH mixes are, by sampling only the source material, with no new gear or samples of my own being used, so my 'One Thousand Dances' mix offered here is quite literally just a rearranging of the Magic Arrows DNA, albeit with a bit of a Wobbly worship going on throughout.



Next up, a night-time bus ride of melancholic techno, in a lovingly made version of 'Duskfriends' by Dusklark, one of my closest friends and a fantastically talented mind. There's a little bit of 85-92 in this mix, but there's also a lot of other things, and none of it would be there without the strains of almost-sadness running through Dusklark's moody movements. This mix remains a personal favorite of mine, and I'm excited to finally include it in the Cmx series here. 



Closing the set is the 17-minute Evaporant mix of Goran Geto's 'Atmosfera' from 2018's 'Atmosfera Jedan' album. This mix was originally released with some very different mastering, done by the late Geto himself, and I've always wanted to publish my original session because of how much more humid and warm it sounded. Here, it beautifully dovetails a set of psychedelic bedroom techno music, with lush sweeps of white noise and spattered dub textures over chordal shapes and subdued rhythms. 



Altogether, it's impressive to me that in addition to all of the work I've published, that there could be this many volumes alone of CH remixes, and still more not yet collected here too. With the release of XV, a second 8xCD Cmx box set is now possible, and a cumulative release collecting volumes VIII-XV will soon arrive. For now, I hope you enjoy this unexpected album made from my own work and the work of four other talented producers, as an accompaniment to the late-Spring and early-Summer weather.

Coppice Halifax.title: Deep Earth: Year Five Compleat
Coppice Halifax.about:
Three years delayed in being collected here, the fifth year of the Deep Earth series finally arrives in totality as a single monolithic set. Spanning no less than 27 discs of music, laid across 93 tracks, Deep Earth Year Five runs over 25 hours in length - allowing you to mine the invisible subcontinent for a full day without resurfacing. 



These recordings were, in many respects, done in a state of transition. In 2020, the pandemic descended upon us, and at the same time, I began to develop a modular system for the first time, after several years of working exclusively with "in the box" hardware and DAWs to meet my musical needs. The introduction of both of these things into my creative approach meant that something as "borderlands" as Deep Earth would only get even further out, or perhaps the better term would be further down, as I dealt with the stress of the virus-infiltrated world and explored new frontiers of generative music, sound design and processing. Throughout the year, it seemed to become a balanced equation - whenever the world would impose itself upon me, my work would pull me further away from it - and so it is this sonic riptide that Deep Earth Year Five documents quite well. 



The Deep Earth sessions presented here illustrate patch development and improvisation using a number of very specific machines, from Behringer's MS-1 reiteration of Roland's SH-101 monosynth (a machine I'd always dreamt of owning) to Korg's Volca Modular, my first additive synthesizer styled after the "West coast" sound of Don Buchla's instruments. You will hear IK Multimedia's Uno Drum, a unique drum machine that is half analog and half digital, as well as experimental techno "grown" out of single clicks of a 3340 VCO that's been sampled and shaped by a granular processor and other modular tools. There's also the inclusion of what could be my favorite ambient music I recorded that year, in both versions of 'Hierau' created using a multitrack tape machine and the Volca Sample. Other notable appearances are 'Veka' - my first session successfully deciphering how to make the Grass Click-Tone Control Module track pitch sequencing, which is easier said than done with a device designed for medical testing rather than studio instrumentation - and deep techno excursions like 'Ovo' which employ a minimum of equipment, such as the tuned five-voice resonator in the Alesis Quadraverb, two delay paths and a Digitech pitch shifter, to generate huge masses of alien and psychedelic sound. 



Year Five covers a lot of (under)ground, which is omnipresent beneath the surface of my more mainstream work, and hopefully demonstrates how and where I find many of my sound design ideas for more composed work as Milieu and Coppice Halifax. Following Year Five, Deep Earth would descend further into a meta-narrative arc with only twelve singular pieces, all rigidly composed, before entering a state of hibernation to make way for the interim Abyssal Geology series, which has continued for the last year and a half. In this way, Year Five is the last leg of Deep Earth to really resemble Deep Earth as it was conceived initially, and perhaps this is a good thing, considering just how much material has been generated by this project. 



The intent was always a "cycle" of eight years of EARTH catalog releases, so as of this writing, two more years still remain to be explored, but the world has changed a lot since I started Deep Earth in 2015, and my work has always existed reactively beside the state of that world. Deep Earth has always been defined by curiosity and uncertainty, a willful discarding of confidence and fear of errors as I lower myself and my equipment into the abyss. What I find is what I find, and what I do not find or do not understand is down there too. Whether I am documenting the process or not, Deep Earth lies beneath the surface in waiting, occasionally splintering open to reveal an entry point such as this one you stand before now. 



---

N.B. Deep Earth currently offers a yearly subscription service, which costs $83, and includes the entirety of Year Six, over 100 different subscriber-exclusive recordings, a reusable discount code for anything in the catalog (from Year One to Year Five) and of course all material released within a calendar year following your subscription. You can explore Deep Earth here:  malfokusita.bandcamp.com  More details about the overall project as well as what is included when you subscribe are here:  www.patreon.com/posts/95024300

Coppice Halifax.title: Deep Earth: Year Six Compleat
Coppice Halifax.about:
The monolithic sixth year of the Deep Earth series, finally collected here with all twelve subscription-exclusive EPs (which are functionally a darker 'alternate universe' version of the Astral Salons series). Extremely limited quantities of a dustproof ring-binder 16xCD box set are available while they last.



---





The sixth year of the Deep Earth series unexpectedly became the last, at least at the time of this writing. Although the overall plan for the series was an eight-year run, the sixth year proved so exhausting to complete that by the end, it was decided that the series would pause, and give way to a less formalized and more exploratory sub-series called Abyssal Geology. As of this moment, Abyssal Geology is about to enter its third consecutive year, although I can also firmly state that the final two years of Deep Earth will still be recorded and released, but I simply don't yet know when. 



Time has always been at the center of Deep Earth, in the sense of both rhythmic time and entropic time, and as the mantra of the series states - "Tempo Pulsos Malfokusita" - time pulses out of focus. This observation held doubly true when I'd more or less written myself into a corner with the series. Each year of Deep Earth, whether it was made apparent or not, came with a monthly narrative text accompaniment that filled out additional contexts for the sound and the amorphous light-trail visuals. This narrative existed in eight year-long arcs that were presented in non-chronological ordering, and by the end of the eight year run, it would be apparent that they also functioned recursively. 



Year Six, which lies before you, is operatively the "first" narrative section of Deep Earth, and as such, it required a much more rigid and predetermined process of composition in order to be created - a process not unlike previous scoring jobs I'd taken on for video games or film. The narrative details a person (who may or may not resemble a fictionalized self-portrait) who is drafted into doing research for a clandestine corporation, living and working on site in a high-security lab facility to study and hopefully learn more about an artifact called the Ur Slate. The Slate is a four-sided obelisk, bearing a variant of Babylonian cuneiform on all four sides, and it was excavated from beneath the Antarctic ice after a seismic event created an anomalous magnetic field there in 1956. Things are not quite what they seem to be, and the story goes through some hopefully fascinating changes that lend a deeper weight to the very abstract music. 



Without going further into the explanation and analysis of what I've assembled here, a few things bear mentioning, and are perhaps obvious. First, the entire story I'd dreamt up for Year Six was, in hindsight, analogous to my changing relationships with the machines I'd been using for years to create this series, as well as a commentary on the creative act itself. Second, the amount of time I'd invested in filling out the details of Year Six pales in comparison to many other projects I've done - from researching real-world sites and events in the Antarctic, to reading about the chemical composition of what seawater in the Precambrian age might have been, to lining up dates on a timeline with seismic events and even the technology that would have been available to exhume something from deep underground in 1956. It was fun to do, but in the end I needed a break from the whole thing, and it was hard to feel as if going back to a totally different leg of the Deep Earth narrative the following year would be anything but disappointing. 



So as I sit here now, three years later to the month, listening to the music again with fresh ears, reading my attempt at weird fiction and meta-narrative (even though I continue to maintain that I am only ever moonlighting as a "writer" and do not wish to be taken seriously as one), Year Six is one of the most unique things I've ever done, and I've released a lot of things. It's surrealistic, both musically and textually, and I find it compelling to engage with even without all of my hyper-detailed contexts. Several of my earliest strides with modular synthesis happened in Year Six, as well as landmark recordings made in a number of wildly different approaches - everything from multiple microphone feedback setups to recording/overdubbing/pitch correcting appliances, granular sampling experiments that blur the line between diegetic sound for a film that doesn't exist and haunted field recordings - and my personal favorite composition I'd recorded throughout the '21 year on EARTH 70, which consists of only the ARP 2600. All of my influences from the classical electronic world are placed front and center on Year Six - Radigue, Lucier, Carlos, Stockhausen, Eno and many others, as well as my modern idols like Vainio, Chartier, Nakajima, Burraston and Voigt, just to list off a few easy ones - and in this way Year Six becomes one big weird love letter to synthesis itself. 



I hope, if you're still reading this, you'll step with me into the dark room and see what I've found. I've collected here all twelve months of Year Six's public-facing run (EARTH 61-72) and all twelve accompanying subscriber-exclusive EPs (FORJETITAJ 61-72) that provide a smaller narrative timeline (the 1956 excavation) as well as offer, in many ways, a much more experimental parallel-universe version of the Astral Salons series, which was recorded at the same time. The whole thing spans sixteen discs of work that I sincerely think stands apart from the entirety of the Coppice Halifax catalog to date. Just press play, close your eyes and remember that time pulses out of focus - see you on the other side.



---



N.B. Deep Earth currently offers a yearly subscription service, which costs $83, and includes the entirety of Year Six, over 100 different subscriber-exclusive recordings, a reusable discount code for anything in the catalog (from Year One to Year Five) and of course all material released within a calendar year following your subscription. You can explore Deep Earth here:  malfokusita.bandcamp.com  More details about the overall project as well as what is included when you subscribe are here:  www.patreon.com/posts/95024300

Coppice Halifax.title: Shades of Night in Green Minor
Coppice Halifax.about:
Happy Green Saturday, to all who celebrate. Having wandered into a weird Springtime, I am happy to offer you a pipe of four Halifaxian cultivars, some of which have been plucked from the workshop archives of over a decade past. Despite this, Shades of Night picks up directly where the CH dub of Milieu's "Mural Hex" left off, and this path will continue forward later in the Summer on the Transient Logics album. 



"Ceremonial" is the oldest, and opens the starry-eyed affair with far too much sub-bass, subtly microtonal synth lines and percussion shaped from fireworks on an old Akai 12-bit sampler. It was recorded almost immediately following the sessions for Leaf Cloak in 2013-2014, close enough at the time that I felt a bit regretful over not having been able to include it on that album. It cured on the shelves for years, initially being passed around to other dub techno labels, who all inevitably turned it down, likely because it isn't really dub or techno, but some liminal gradient between the two. 



"In Green" meanders in with a slower tempo and a softer approach, most resembling Dusk Versions and the precedent Analog Botany series with its sinewave bassline, cratedigger percussions and more 12-bit sampler chords. Halfway through, modernity arrives with a Poly 800 bassline and a firmer house beat, which is slowly surrounded by SEM chords and leads and even more FM synths. 



"Unison" is or was the problem child of the group, with a cozy but inoffensively boring original mix that I decided would be better served as foundational mortar for something more developed and exciting, with copious layering of new parts. So little of the original mix remains intact here that I could publish the track as a totally separate entry here, but I enjoy this fresh take so much more. It offers a melodic and colorful "side two" counterpoint to "Ceremonial," with a more complex polymetric structure that allows danceable and hypnotic arrangements to do their work. 



"Surrendered" is the longest cut on offer, gently pulling us out into the dark waves from an empty beach. With its Galaxy Maker swoons of synthetic strings and motorik bassline, it brings me back to many different times and places through the years, many of them wistful and sweetly melancholic. By the end, the disco has sunk beneath the glistening surface of the sea, leaving only a disembodied cluster of melodies to float further out. A theme emerges, retreats, dissipates in an echo. I wave goodbye, but this is only goodbye for a while. My vessel will return later on, sunburnt and saltwater baptized, with unimagined secrets and perfumes in tow.

Coppice Halifax.title: Cedar Mast [Expanded & Remastered]
Coppice Halifax.about:
Arriving slightly delayed (laid...laid...laid...perfect for a dub album) for it's tenth anniversary celebration is CEDAR MAST, an album of minimalistic techno that was built using only samples of the Sega Dreamcast's boot menu and a Korg sampler, aided in part by samples of archaic drum machines like Mattel's Synsonics and Yamaha's MR-10.



CEDAR MAST conveys a set of straightforward dry techno mixes that bubble with white noise and the watery washes of Dreamcast samples. These tracks exist on the rim of monochromaticism, echoing both the ANALOG BOTANY sessions that preceded them and the LEAF CLOAK sessions that would follow. Alongside the five original tracks, I've also included the "Rebuild" that opened the CEDAR MIXES collection of reworks - a non-album cut that was fashioned using only the loops and materials offered to other artists who were invited to participate. 



For the second half, CEDAR MAST REDUCED mutates the material into something more experimental and Chain Reaction-inspired, which provided a precursory look at the sound of DEEP EARTH, still yet to come at the time. This second disc has been augmented with a 2022 EXCAVATION, a new nearly hour-long session of soft-focus dub, created using the same machines and samples as the original album, a decade later.



There is a surprising amount of vagueness I feel now, with regard to adding anything prosaic to the topic of CEDAR MAST. Any sentiment I could think to express is very clearly and fully articulated somewhere in the dense surrealism of the music, and what initially began as a proof-of-concept experiment with sampling and already-outdated video game consoles in mind clearly navigated itself into many different atmospheres both above and below the forests and seashores of the Halifaxian continent. CEDAR MAST resembles many different facets of my work through the years, and so it feels that much more elementally a part of my creative landscape, rather than something that might occupy it. 



Revisiting material from a decade ago has become, somewhat comically, a predictable exercise, although it is not without a fair share of challenges, all of which I am willing to forge a new path through in order to hopefully reinstate something in its best possible iteration, and maybe, if I'm lucky, rediscover what possessed me to do these things in the first place. CEDAR MAST is an anomalous ship in a nonlinear sea, and I've done my very best to update and maintain it in order to see it off for another ten years - perhaps when that time has passed, we will see if I have succeeded.



N.B. - A very limited edition of 10 copies of the 2xCD-R reissue has been made available for the occasion, first come first serve as always. If you've missed out, and you really can't live with yourself, please get in touch in all the usual ways and I'll see what I can do.

Coppice Halifax.title: CMR Pillar Excavation
Coppice Halifax.about: The CMR Pillar Excavation is a new forty-minute session of polymetric ambient techno, courting shades of dub music and drifty generative synthesis across its runtime. It was recorded in late 2022 using only the boot sounds of the Sega Dreamcast video game system in tandem with several different hardware samplers and an array of outboard FX. It was drafted in celebration of the tenth anniversary of the Cedar Mast album, and is included in an expanded and remastered edition of that release (  coppicehalifax.bandcamp.com/album/cedar-mast-expanded-remastered  ) but I've opted to give it a singular release also, separated from the reissue, in order to both allow it to exist as a new piece of cataloged music, as well as give listeners the opportunity to bypass the reissued decade-old material and simply access what's new.

Coppice Halifax.title: Blue Cloak
Coppice Halifax.about:
Ten years ago in April 2013, the Leaf Cloak album was published, and both symbolically as well as aesthetically began what I now consider my post-Analog Botany phase of Coppice Halifax recordings. The album's sessions were long and varied, yielding no less than two full-length albums of original takes, a remix album and a beatless ambient companion piece, as well as numerous stray mixes that would be released piecemeal in the years to come. Somewhere in that frenzied process, I'd begun work on yet another variant of the Leaf Cloak sound, bringing together samples from all prior versions into a new set of shapes that would feel familiar, but also sit apart from the rest of the mixes. These pieces would never be finished until this year, as I approached the tenth anniversary of the Leaf Cloak album, and now they have finally arrived - a Blue Cloak, aptly named from beneath the downpours of this very rainy Spring season. 



Blue Cloak is three sidelong (in vinyl terms) assemblages of ambient music, analog textures and noise, dub rhythms and basslines, and a wealth of filter-warped and delay-spattered chords. It was created using elements from all six Leaf Cloak tracks, tape loops harvested from the Chemist Cloak bent-cassette dubs and even some of the hardware that was used on the original sessions, such as the Roland SH-32 synthesizer and the Korg ER-1/Boss DR-660/DR-880 drum machines. 



The resultant recordings accomplish finally what I set out to do a decade ago, to make deeper and more tangential pieces of dubby atmosphere and groove that referred to Leaf Cloak in topical ways, while also using the parts and processes to create completely new sounds. In many ways, I am glad I did not finish the work I started until now, as my current fascinations with polymetric sequencing and generative synthesis have helped to inform the work in ways that would simply not have been possible all those years ago. 



Blue Cloak is also intended as a herald for the imminent Leaf Cloak reissue set that I hope to complete preparations for by the end of Summer. The plan is to assemble a box set that collects Leaf Cloak, Ash Cloak and Chemist Cloak alongside Blue Cloak and perhaps a fifth disc of stray mixes and other ephemera from the period. The beatless fantasist pastorale Mistmorning, a split project with close friend and frequent collaborator Zwei Kreise, will also see a reissue, which may or may not include expanded material also. For the moment, Blue Cloak felt appropriate to be issued ahead of these arrangements, for the Spring season, and simply as a proper album in its own right. 



Happy Spring from Coppice Halifax, and I hope you'll join me in wishing Leaf Cloak a happy tenth anniversary also!

Coppice Halifax.title: Cmx XIII
Coppice Halifax.about:
Somewhat surprisingly, it has already been four and a half years since the twelfth volume in the Cmx series was issued. For one reason (or several), I've been preoccupied enough with other albums and projects that continuing this archival thread of remix collections slipped away from me. With Autumn's leafy breeze now fully within the lungs of the valley, I could not be happier to sit down and assemble another compilation of Coppice mixes, so here's what Cmx thirteen contains: 



Opening the album, as is the usual Cmx custom, is an original cut - the 'Rust Flex' mix of Appleblue Dram, a hardware live set from May 2018 (see:  coppicehalifax.bandcamp.com/album/appleblue-dram  ) which was originally issued at Arctic Dub in Portugal on a 2019 compilation. This mix and master of the track has never been released up to now, with the Arctic Dub compilation having been mastered by the label at the time. Trainspotters will note a *lot* more low end is present in this version. 



Next is a ten-minute dub techno space-out I constructed for Specta Ciera (aka Drexon Field) for his superb Terrain Scan LP issued at Recycled Plastics in 2019. This mix was built using sampled sections from all over the Terrain Scan album, but primarily used melodic information from 'Star Sector' and 'Pattern Scanner', and echoes the kind of post-Analog Botany dub I was making in 18 and 19. Until now, it has only been made available as a bonus track on the Terrain Scan CD-R. 



At number three, we have the inimitable Foamek, with one of two mixes I made for his totally essential On Doing/Being Ordinary companion disc, Avalon (Remixes). My 'Dripping Lawn' mix is the longest track presented here, at nearly 18 minutes, and careens through late-night coastline cruises with neon highs and shadowy lows, recontextualizing Foamek's vocal samples into a DX-like space chorus, and running a Kompakt-inspired bassline beneath the proceedings. 



Fourth is the heaviest and most aggressive of the six tracks offered here, my 'Triadic Phaseout' of Substak's 'Index', which nearly resembles something like Bike more than a CH cut, but I'm sure I had my reasons in Summer 2018. This one was a disc-exclusive cut for the CD-R edition of Index, although it made a brief appearance on one of the Conference Call compilations at RP after the fact. Lots of polymeter that amounts to an almost drum and bass rave up, thick and angular with plenty of DSP warping and break chopping. 



After the romp of the Substak mix, it felt pertinent to pull the intensity back a bit and my remix of Arbee's 'Chaine' more than accomplishes this need. Originally issued on Polysemie III, at Unknown Tone Records in early 2020, this version of the remix is my own master, previously unreleased. Filled with warbling tape spool effects and low-bit Akai sampler sounding passages of bass and synth, this mix recalls my perennial influences from Mille Plateaux atmospherics and early Vladislav Delay records. A lovely off-grid spattering of noise and melody that dovetails the album beautifully into the spacious closer...



And closing the set is my 'Lunar Debris' mix for Dérive Dub (aka Dimitar Dodovsky) on his Notte Variations album at Recycled Plastics, in early 2019. Like tracks #2 and 4, this mix was also a disc-exclusive bonus cut on the CD-R edition of Notte Variations, and has remained offline until now. A breezy night-time dub with elemental textures woven throughout, taking influence from all the Echospace material I was listening to almost constantly at the time, specifically Phase 90 and Variant.

Coppice Halifax.title: Cmx XIV
Coppice Halifax.about: What seems like a shorter volume of only four tracks for the fourteenth Cmx album is in fact a deceptively deep 67 minutes of ambient techno and minimal dub music. Opening with a previously unreleased mix of 'Refocus' that was shelved in the archives as a rehearsal, Cmx XIV establishes the foggy Gaussian mood that will follow throughout the duration. The second cut is a rare mix for Response=Signal, which was included only as a bonus track on the CD-R release at Recycled Plastics, and this mix meanders polymetrically through a soft haze, inspired by Dettinger and Wolfgang Voigt's M:I:5 material, among other Profan recordings. Following this is the Sunthaw mix of Parallelism's 'Ice Ghosts,' previously unreleased until now, and perfect to curl up inside while the Winter cold stays outside. Closing the set is the expansive 35-minute April Valley Nights mix of Foamek's 'Avalon' - also a disc-exclusive bonus track at Recycled Plastics - which offers a spacious and psychedelic pasture of new wave rave bass, crumbling tape loop textures and a persistent heartbeat of a waterlogged drum machine.
