Coppice Halifax.title: Pawleys Island [10th Anniversary Dub]
Coppice Halifax.about:
Ten years ago, in a humid Carolinian October in 2011, I issued the first edition of Pawleys Island - an album that represents many different things, personally and creatively, in the Halifaxian landscape. A decade passing over this double-album seems to have phased it none, as I don't mind admitting that Pawleys has remained such a staple of interest in the Milieu Music catalog that it has not once gone out of print since it was first released. The first edition was a double-cassette, housed in a very finite amount of dustproof audiobook cases that were mailed to me by a very generous librarian friend in New Zealand, whose library was emptying out a lot of old cassette stock. This edition came and went very quickly, leading almost immediately to a 2xCD-R edition, which has since returned through three different iterations, and is still available today. 



So, how then do you celebrate a 10th anniversary for a special record that has never gone out of circulation? Making this process more difficult is the additional fact that there are more or less zero outtakes or extra material from Pawleys' sessions, considering the entirety of the 2010 Analog Botany series of 12 monthly EPs was the creative process I designed to "filter out" my favorite tracks across a whole year of recording, which were then built into Pawleys Island in 2011. Analog Botany, in and of itself, is all Pawleys Island outtakes, and vice versa. 



After months of consideration, the decision was made to simply return to the principal format of the release - a double-cassette reissue for 2021. Initially, I attempted to dig out the original master cassettes to dub new copies from, but being in storage for 10 years, in three different studios (two of which were sweltering and humid rooms in the deep South), the time and transport has not been kind to them. Other financial and material roadblocks emerged as well - tape duplication is far too expensive in 2021 to be done professionally, and even blank cassettes purchased in bulk are much more expensive than they used to be. After locating a stash of suitable tapes for sale second-hand in England, I was ecstatic to jump back into a new dub of Pawleys. I cleaned the heads of my Alesis TapeLink deck and my much older JVC KD-A11 deck in preparation, and even arranged a brand new set of master dubs, somewhat revised to allow for less high-end distortion and some ducking/clipping that was present on the original tapes, and went to work dubbing each side one copy at a time. Two months and eighty 60-minute sides later, I have a reissued double-cassette edition in the same 20-copy print run as the first one in 2011. 



That is where the similarities end, however. Between my second-hand cassettes of unknown origin shipped from across the Atlantic, my aging tape machines and, for all I know, the incongruity of adapting Carolinian techno to Ohioan electronics in climes and elevation levels 600 miles separated, these 20 re-dubs of Pawleys Island manifested with their age and weathering in full focus. At first, this frustrated me - why can't anything in the analog world ever be easy? After a few weeks of relistening, redubbing, trying different signal-flow options and various other methods, I realized Pawleys still sounds good on crumbly and inconsistent cassette tape. I even began to wonder if perhaps it sounded renewed in this light, as paradoxically opposed as that interpretation may be? 



So what you see and hear before you is not a picture-perfect reiteration of the past. It is by no means crystal clear, high-fidelity or ageless. This is the sound of Pawleys Island, ten years wizened, calling out from beneath waves of ferric noise and analog mutation. It echoes the very real-world Pawleys Island, which these days is a corporation-curated vacation spot in an area of nothing but corporate interests and yearly tourism money - not at all the subtropical and sun-cast fantasy I remember from my childhood, running around marshy shores in swim trunks with a sand pail and a plastic shovel, digging up clams and crabs and crawfish, chasing my sister with tigertails and passing out in a blissful Summer haze on the van ride back home again. 



That Pawleys Island is long gone, and likely already was even before I moved away from the state in 2016. Much like the electric plant's twin stacks next to Lake Busbee being demolished, the lake drained out into swampland, Pawleys Island is now a place that only really exists here, on these two eroded cassette tapes, a comfortable escape route taken across spooled brown lines that wobble and bend just like the dirt roads I biked down so many times, bound inland, by night. 



What remains is this tableaux of sonic matter, smeared names on a rain-soaked map, fuzzy radio reception, melodies dripping out of a car speaker, a memorial of so many sad nights of teenage longing, the emptiness of vapid parties, the pointless and boundless beach parties happening only because there was never anything else to do. The forever heavy sensation that the real world, full of real and sincere experiences, was just out of reach. A dangerous borderland of modernity that seemed to laugh down at this little coastline of people, drinking and smoking and pilling themselves senseless, because the boredom of not knowing yourself was too much to bear. I didn't make Pawleys until years after I'd moved away from the beach, I couldn't have - it had to manifest when and where it did, a year before I would become a father, during what was in many ways the height of my salad days, though you can never really know those are over until they've slipped away. There's a naivete present in these recordings, a portrait of a place and time painted out beautifully with all of the sorrow left out, perhaps even stirring the notion that Pawleys Island is out there still, a hidden everglade waiting to be happened upon by inebriated teenagers who cannot discern what's a blurry hallucination and what isn't. This album is for them, joyfully ignorant of the life that awaits them, dancing on the graves of lovestruck soldiers and hurricane-swept ruins, where tomorrow never comes. I'm glad to be away and apart from these things and these people now, even if I was one of them in what seems like another lifetime before this one. 



Pawleys Island thrums on, heart-beating kick drums and Mellon Collie chords flooding over my bedroom carpet like a high tide rushing in, Atlantic seawater filling up a midwestern valley, soon enough carrying me back down into the sea like some dream-flume bound by the guilty gravities of Deep Earth itself. Happy tenth birthday - we'll see what the water washes up in another ten years.

Coppice Halifax.title: WPX Versions
Coppice Halifax.about:
Originally recorded in Spring of 2021, without any impetus to do so, these two variations on material from the White Pillar sessions were laid to tape and subsequently shelved for a future release. Revisiting them now, in November, when the wind has turned cold and wet, and all the green leaves that were coming to life when these pieces were recorded are now piled up across my lawn in dripping patches of orange, brown and purple, brings to mind a sense of real distance being traveled, and this feels appropriate to address, given the state of intense transition I've been going through this Autumn. 



WPX VERSIONS exists in a unique state that is neither present nor past - it recalls other shapes and times, conveyed through the ever-changing prism of my studio equipment's configuration, and yet it more accurately resembles the ASTRAL SALONS catalog, rather than the White Pillar series it originates from. Perhaps these lines being drawn around projects are detected only by my ears, which must certainly be worn out after so many years of constant need being placed upon them, so I submit these recordings to you in the hopes that they bring you happiness and fantasist escapism at the end of another very long, very dark and very difficult year.
Coppice Halifax.credits:

Recorded at White Pillar Workshop, Spring 2021, using elements from the White Pillar sessions alongside several samplers (Akai S2800, Boss RC-20, Korg ES-1, KP-2 and Volca Sample and the PVDJ Grabber) and field recordings from different locations and dates in the past. Mastered by The Analog Botanist, Autumn 2021. Design and text by ABM&D. Photograph taken at Rolling Knoll, Summer 2016. This is Milieu Music number WPWS21.  www.milieu-music.com   www.analogbotany.com

Coppice Halifax.title: Lust's Nightly Glories
Coppice Halifax.about:
"We feel the long pulsation, ebb and flow of endless motion, the tones of unseen mystery, the vague and vast suggestions of the

briny world, the liquid-flowing syllables, the perfume, the faint creaking of the cordage, the melancholy rhythm, the boundless vista and the horizon far and dim are all here, and this is ocean's poem."



-Whitman, 1900



Lust's Nightly Glories was an alternative arrangement of the Coastal Reveries album, which was privately commissioned in 2012 by visual artist and designer Dylan Fisher. It was created for the purpose of providing a more ambient and minimalist portrayal of the Coastal Reveries material, where many of the higher frequency bands were reduced, details were smoothed over and various other post-processing decisions were made concerning pitch, sequencing and texture. Additionally, the album features a completely different backdrop from Coastal Reveries, a blend of field recordings, white and pink noise generators, self-oscillating FX75B flange and other tangible sounds designed to provide a wide lens space for the ambient tonal material to spread out inside. At the time of its creation, it was offered to Fisher alongside Coastal Reveries as a bonus item, an extra bit of gratitude for such a gracious commission, and over time it has taken on more and more gravity in my memory, now feeling as if it can provide an equally potent counterpoint to Coastal Reveries. It was this feeling that informed my decision to offer Lust's Nightly Glories as its own separately reissued release, rather than a bonus disc for Coastal Reveries, and now, almost a decade later, I'm happy to finally give it a distinct place in my catalog for public consumption and consideration.
Coppice Halifax.credits:
released October 1, 2021
            
            W/P by Brian Grainger. Recorded at Botany Bay, Autumn 2012. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. Text by ABM&D. Painting by Victor Stember (1909) with post-processing by ABM&D. This is Milieu Music number MMD057B. (c) + (p) Oscillog ASCAP 2021. All nights preserved.

Coppice Halifax.title: Porch Compost In Shade
Coppice Halifax.about:
Following the two EPs of Porch Hash Variations, themselves transfigurations of the field recording triptych Porch Hash Logbook (see:  briangrainger.bandcamp.com/album/porch-hash-logbook  ), are two subsequent EPs of "night versions" undertaken in the grand tradition of re-dubbing the dubs. 



These tracks further mutate and saturate the original sessions into soporific washes of blue chords, crashing distantly upon glittering shores and rock faces in sprays of soft pink noise and light-trails of reverb. A lone kick drum anchors almost every cut, a heartbeat from deep below the surface of the Earth, present but also passive beneath the huge whorls of dub sonics that float upon it. 



On a technical level, the original Porch Hash tracks were sublimated by way of mid-side EQ work, separating out mono and stereo information, and routing it through various FX processors and other mixing destinations. Also employed were deliberate downsampling passes of the source material, riding the cusp of extremely lossy digital bit reduction, just enough to remove all the high end and round off all the edges. The final mix was done after all of these prepped sound files were in hand, using two archaic samplers (an Akai S2800 and a Korg ES-1) in conjunction with supplemental processing via my R-EW Audioholistics modular system.
Coppice Halifax.credits:

Coppice Halifax.title: Astral Salons [Phase 8]
Coppice Halifax.about:
Another year, another series, another branch in the long path of exploring my creative continents. 2021 brings us to ASTRAL SALONS, a nine-section series of monthly EP installments that land somewhere between STATIC PHARMING and SILHOUETTES, bridging the corporeal and the cosmic in concise twenty-minute jaunts that are designed to groove and meander in equal measure, and hopefully do not overstay their welcome. The digital 4x12" FERINE ALEMBIX could be seen as a precursor for this series, as those sessions put me back in the mood to produce an EP series again, and further, ASTRAL SALONS are not just informed by their more "modest" runtimes, but also a very fresh and unique approach to modulation, stereo panning and sonic depth-of-field that I've played with in the past, but haven't yet focused so completely upon until now.



Paired with these sessions are nine Polaroids shot using expired film, on the day of the August 21st, 2017 total solar eclipse. I felt that these images were appropriate analogs for the concept of the series, being surrealist and psychedelic multi-layered pieces with deliberately lossy artifacting, overexposed processing and overlaps of FX processes in motion that leave "holes" in the sound field. The photographs are presented as they were developed, with only some contrasting and digital cleanup work done in post, again mirroring my studio process for the ASTRAL SALONS sessions.
Coppice Halifax.credits:
released August 6, 2021
            
            W/P by Brian Grainger. Recorded at White Pillar, July 2021. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. Text and photography by ABM&D. This is Milieu Music number PHASE 8, eighth in the ASTRAL SALONS subcatalog.

Coppice Halifax.title: Porch Compost In Ash
Coppice Halifax.about:
Following the two EPs of Porch Hash Variations, themselves transfigurations of the field recording triptych Porch Hash Logbook (see:  briangrainger.bandcamp.com/album/porch-hash-logbook  ), are two subsequent EPs of "night versions" undertaken in the grand tradition of re-dubbing the dubs. 



These tracks further mutate and saturate the original sessions into soporific washes of blue chords, crashing distantly upon glittering shores and rock faces in sprays of soft pink noise and light-trails of reverb. A lone kick drum anchors almost every cut, a heartbeat from deep below the surface of the Earth, present but also passive beneath the huge whorls of dub sonics that float upon it. 



On a technical level, the original Porch Hash tracks were sublimated by way of mid-side EQ work, separating out mono and stereo information, and routing it through various FX processors and other mixing destinations. Also employed were deliberate downsampling passes of the source material, riding the cusp of extremely lossy digital bit reduction, just enough to remove all the high end and round off all the edges. The final mix was done after all of these prepped sound files were in hand, using two archaic samplers (an Akai S2800 and a Korg ES-1) in conjunction with supplemental processing via my R-EW Audioholistics modular system.
Coppice Halifax.credits:
released May 7, 2021
            
            W/P by Brian Grainger. Recorded at White Pillar, April 2021. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. Design & text by ABM&D, processing original paintings by Arnold Böcklin. This is Milieu Music number ABX420C2.  milieu-music.com   analogbotany.com

Coppice Halifax.title: Familiar Shores
Coppice Halifax.about: When the 10th anniversary of the original COASTAL REVERIES session approached, and the first public edition of the album was being updated with a current remastering job, I felt compelled to explore the source material a bit more intimately, as I have for several other remasters, in the interest of producing something new with/from the sonic compost. The result of that tangent is FAMILIAR SHORES, a double-album collecting two longform sessions of excavation that transfigure melodic and field recording content from COASTAL REVERIES over/under a warm sinewave bassline and a kick-drum heartbeat. The two pieces presented here could be considered a missing link between COASTAL REVERIES and things like VERDANT ACRE or OCEAN LION - they are subtropical, saltwater-splashed affairs that still feel terrestrial enough in their Earthy rhythms and chordal longing to indicate that they are not fully oceanic, but stranded on the beach, gazing out to an empty sea, perhaps even considering walking into the waves without a single glance back. FAMILIAR SHORES are aptly named, as they conjure up a sensation of having been here before, despite being altogether unmapped locations. Another romantic excursion up one of the many coastlines of the Halifaxian continent, marked in the travelogue, as the sun sets slowly on another long droned Summer, our footprints almost surely erased as the tide rolls back in.
Coppice Halifax.credits:
released August 6, 2021
            
            W/P by Brian Grainger. Recorded at White Pillar Workshop, Spring 2021 using musical audio and field recordings from Coastal Reveries (MMD057) as source. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. Cover design and photography by Eric Adrian Lee. Text, labels and disc faces by ABM&D. This is Milieu Music Distributed MMD059. (C) + (P) Oscillog ASCAP 2021. All nights preserved.  www.milieu-music.com   www.analogbotany.com

Additional thanks to the subscribers at Deep Earth and Vibratelepathos.  www.patreon.com/analogbotany   malfokusita.bandcamp.com   vibratelepathos.bandcamp.com

Coppice Halifax.title: Porch Hash Variations [Cide A]
Coppice Halifax.about:
Following the field-recording triptych Porch Hash Logbook, an exercise in acoustic minimalism and wordless diaries, I pursued a tangent of exploring the possible applications of these field recordings within the framework of dub music. Forming an ouroboros of sorts, these tracks transfigure the sound of THC-doused outdoors into smoky and syrupy deep techno.



The recordings were routed through various channels of my R-EW Audioholistics modular system, as well as the vocoder within the Arturia Microfreak and reverberation units such as the Alesis Quadraverb, the Pioneer SR-202W and the Lexicon Alex. Over and under these processing scenarios, I played a Korg ES-1 sampler, which handled basic drumkit and bassline duties, and the final summed mix was sent into a DAW with numerous automation and modulation envelopes, rhythmic gates and slicers and additional FX. Finally, live takes were recorded wherein I'd nudge and pull on the gates and tempo grid, setting into motion many interesting mutations of the source material.



Sonically, these pieces are influenced by early Vladislav Delay, many records in the Chain Reaction catalog, many of Rod Modell's records for Soma, Intrusion, wzrdryAV and JS Zeiter. They are deep and dubbed out compost, with sounds that will likely appeal to fans of Leaf Cloak, Pharmlands/Static Pharming and Verdant Acre.



These sessions were immediately followed by a subsequent session of more minimalistic reductions, which are being released separately with the appended label "Porch Compost" - to be issued on May 7.
Coppice Halifax.credits:
released April 20, 2021
            
            W/P by Brian Grainger. Recorded at White Pillar, April 2021. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. Design & text by ABM&D, processing original paintings by Hieronymus Bosch. This is Milieu Music number ABX420A.  milieu-music.com   analogbotany.com 



 Many humble thanks to the members of the Milieu Music Fan Club at Patreon  patreon.com/analogbotany  and the subscribers at Deep Earth  malfokusita.bandcamp.com  and Vibratelepathos  vibratelepathos.bandcamp.com  - Without their continued support, these recordings and many others may not have come to fruition.

Coppice Halifax.title: Coastal Reveries
Coppice Halifax.about:
Coastal Reveries was the first of its kind - a privately commissioned work, drafted by Dylan Fisher, a multidisciplinary visual artist in New York, in 2012 - and until now, it has remained unreleased. Although details are foggy, since my daughter was born in April of that same year, I do recall Fisher asking me to create something with a detailed level of specificity in mind. He asked for a recording that could inhabit similar soundworlds as High Hawaiian Fog, Ocean Lion and perhaps other map-points like Verdant Acre - all of these, moments within my catalog that seem to resurface on a regular basis - and I did my damnedest at that moment in time to revisit those spaces, rather than attempt to recreate them. 



In truth, I find the act of remaking not just tedious, but impossible, for any creative mind that is truly inspired, and especially my own, which seems to thrive on tangents, peripheries, wandering exploration...the act of doing has always been far more rewarding for me than any level of familiarity or nostalgia one might expect to come along with re-approaching prior ideas. So, I'm certain that my acceptance of Fisher's commission came along with such a caveat, that I may not be able to fully find my way back the way I came, and that while I could almost guarantee that the resultant recordings would resemble aspects of the things he'd named, they would likely diverge from those albums just as much. 



So, off to work I went, and again, memory being unreliable, I want to say I worked on it all through that Summer and Autumn, because one way or another, I'd finished the album by December, and delivered it to Fisher in both physical and digital capacities, with a signed and dated certificate of authenticity, should he ever decide to sell his copy. The sessions remain a blur for me, and all I can really say with certainty now about them is that I was sampling a vinyl box set of Mantovani material primarily, echoing the orchestral sampling present on High Hawaiian Fog, although the provenance for those tracks varied from Delius and Dvorak to Lee Hazlewood, far less singular and far more experimental on a foundational level. For Coastal Reveries, I wanted something that felt a bit more romantic, 1960s exotica, and Mediterranean honeymoon eloping, rather than Atlantic/southern American nautical fantasy. 



The latter still managed to inform the vantage point of the recordings, however, with all seven tracks named for shorelines in the Carolinas - my way of acknowledging that this entire thing was a vision of longing for and imagining those European waves and ports, channeling them more as a voyeuristic conjurer rather than a seasoned traveler. By the time I'd completed the recordings, I felt genuinely as if this was a Halifaxian album for lovers, a seafoamed score for beached dalliances beneath fluffy white clouds, no doubt filled with the harp-strums of Cupid...these Coastal Reveries would be manifest in both mythical love and animal lust. To accentuate this approach, I penned a modest amount of copy to accompany the record, which was more or less a prosaic scene of sex on the beach, albeit surrealistic and abstract in many of the same ways my writing remains today. 



After a few years, Fisher gave me his blessing to publicly release Coastal Reveries, and plans were made to issue it at Wil Ru Records in Portland, the very same label that brought High Hawaiian Fog to the wider world, but soon after this, WR fell out of the business of issuing new music, and Coastal Reveries was shelved indefinitely. Today, almost nine years later, Reveries has been remastered from the original session tapes, and given a beautiful new visual design by Eric Adrian Lee, a name many listeners will already be familiar with from his work on High Hawaiian Fog, Sun Cast, Summer's Parting Ways and many more albums that are immensely important to me for personal reasons. Eric is a master, perhaps even THE master, of depicting scenes of romance, both bawdy and pastoral, and conveying this oceanic longing through the lens of his lush visual compositions. Lee's design work for Reveries is the perfect companion to the music, and I hope my prose (reprinted on the inner gatefold) lends itself favorably to the listening experience also. 



So, as part of my celebration of my 38th year on this mad Earth, where truth continues to be even more surrealistic than the fictions I summon, I am more than happy to offer you Coastal Reveries, another chapter in the subtropical odyssey I've apparently been writing, not endless, but certainly without an ending in sight or mind. This music would appeal to fans of High Hawaiian Fog, Ocean Lion, Tigress and Sun Cast, but also maintains distinct connections to recordings like Verdant Acre, My Earths and even more modern excursions like Dripping Earth and Silhouettes. Included with your purchase are both indexed and seamless presentations of the album, and following this release will be a few others that are Coastal Reveries-adjacent, from June onward. 



"There's only one thing you can do with a girl like this. Walk naked into the sea together as the sun sets. Make love once... Then die."



-Mick Travis, 1968
Coppice Halifax.credits:
released May 17, 2021
            
            W/P by Brian Grainger. Recorded at Botany Bay, 2012. Commissioned by Dylan Fisher. Remastered by The Analog Botanist at the White Pillar Workshop, 2021. Text accompaniments by ABM&D, except the Mick Travis quote, written by Lindsay Anderson. Design and photography by Eric Adrian Lee. Printing and duplication by Atomic Disc. This is Milieu Music number MMD057.  www.milieu-music.com   www.analogbotany.com   ericadrianleedesign.tumblr.com

Coppice Halifax.title: Photostasis
Coppice Halifax.about: PHOTOSTASIS is an unexpected return to the form and function of STATIC PHYSICS, a 2013 double-album of CH excavations, which mined, repurposed and transfigured sounds from other CH and even Milieu sources. The two tracks presented here explore deep dub techno tangents that rearrange their sonic provenance at the molecular level, aided by the addition of some very Halifaxian sampler/monosynth/drum machine work. This is minimalist techno for the dusky ends of Summer days, a paean to the Golden Hour that may be enjoyed alongside a porch chair, a cold lager or a well-packed spliff. It moves, it doesn't - the music echoes the words printed on the labels, conveying a sense of blissful stillness.
Coppice Halifax.credits:
released July 7, 2021
            
            W/P by Brian Grainger, May 2021. Recorded at White Pillar Workshop, using extracted source sound from XXXXXXXXX YYYYYY ZZZZZZZZZ and AAAAAAAA BBBBBBBBBB, alongside Akai S2800/Korg ES-1 + Volca Sample sampler units, Korg ER-1/Boss DR-660 drum machines and a Behringer TD-3 analog monosynth. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. Design, photography and text by ABM&D. This is Milieu Music number ABX120.  www.milieu-music.com   www.analogbotany.com

Coppice Halifax.title: CVX3
Coppice Halifax.about: Three tracks, sporadically manifesting from the ashes of another minimal techno session from years past (see: Growth Markers -  coppicehalifax.bandcamp.com/album/growth-markers-phase-six-rhythmic-processing-recontextualization  ), that in many ways provide a bridge to other peripheral projects (such as Bike or even Vhom) as well as opening a new path forward for CH to explore. Inspired heavily by the minimalist techno of Mika Vainio / Ø, early SND, the first Sistol album, Thomas Brinkmann, LP5-era AE, Torsten Profrock and modern-era Omit recordings, CVX3 represents the typically glacial metabolic development of a longform CH album, redressed in sounds and events that are much more micro than macro, pointillist and welcoming of spaces and pauses, while still completely embracing of gridded rhythmic dynamism. CVX3 expresses many of these things while also managing to resemble almost nothing from the mainstream CH catalog, save for Deep Earth recordings, which these may very well owe the entirety of their structural makeup to. Greyscale electronic isolationism for minds looking to be momentarily erased.
Coppice Halifax.credits:
released April 2, 2021
            
            W/P by Brian Grainger. Regenerated and engineered at White Pillar, March 2020, using ABX64 as source compost. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. Text and design by ABM&D. Photograph taken by Distrans Telekomm, Antarctica 1956, reproduced with permission. This is Milieu Music number ABX118.  milieu-music.com   analogbotany.com

Coppice Halifax.title: Auroral Phases
Coppice Halifax.about:
AURORAL PHASES consists of two beatless pieces that manifested peripherally during the SILHOUETTES sessions earlier in the Summer. They reflect both the atmospheric texture of SILHOUETTES and the melodic provenance of STATUETTES, the latter being transfigured through my generative process to create the former. These two recordings were included only on a strictly limited edition of 8 copies (four numbered, and four 'artist print' copies) of the 12xCD-R deluxe boxed variant of SILHOUETTES II, and now that this edition is sold out, I felt it was only fair to make AURORAL PHASES available publicly, since I am never interested in deliberately keeping material hard to obtain. Musically, they are deeply calming pieces that I find work well on their own, outside of being appended to SILHOUETTES, and recall aspects of Milieu's ongoing VIBRATELEPATHOS series (((  vibratelepathos.bandcamp.com  ))) in how they were created as well as their sonic personalities. 



NOTE: If you are one of the eight owners of the 12xCD-R SILHOUETTES II set, please only purchase this release if you absolutely must own it. I am planning, subsequent to the AURORAL PHASES release, to send all eight of you free download codes to add this release to your collections. Your continued support is appreciated.
Coppice Halifax.credits:
released February 5, 2021
            
            W/P by Brian Grainger. Recorded at White Pillar, Summer 2020, using Milieu's STATUETTES albums as provenance, laid to tape tangentially during the SILHOUETTES sessions. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. Text and design by ABM&D. This is Milieu Music number ABX116B.  milieu-music.com   analogbotany.com

Coppice Halifax.title: Astral Salons [Phase 2]
Coppice Halifax.about:
Another year, another series, another branch in the long path of exploring my creative continents. 2021 brings us to ASTRAL SALONS, a nine-section series of monthly EP installments that land somewhere between STATIC PHARMING and SILHOUETTES, bridging the corporeal and the cosmic in concise twenty-minute jaunts that are designed to groove and meander in equal measure, and hopefully do not overstay their welcome. The digital 4x12" FERINE ALEMBIX could be seen as a precursor for this series, as those sessions put me back in the mood to produce an EP series again, and further, ASTRAL SALONS are not just informed by their more "modest" runtimes, but also a very fresh and unique approach to modulation, stereo panning and sonic depth-of-field that I've played with in the past, but haven't yet focused so completely upon until now. 



Paired with these sessions are nine Polaroids shot using expired film, on the day of the August 21st, 2017 total solar eclipse. I felt that these images were appropriate analogs for the concept of the series, being surrealist and psychedelic multi-layered pieces with deliberately lossy artifacting, overexposed processing and overlaps of FX processes in motion that leave "holes" in the sound field. The photographs are presented as they were developed, with only some contrasting and digital cleanup work done in post, again mirroring my studio process for the ASTRAL SALONS sessions.
Coppice Halifax.credits:
released February 5, 2021
            
            W/P by Brian Grainger. Recorded at White Pillar, February 2021. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. Text and photography by ABM&D. This is Milieu Music number PHASE 2, second in the ASTRAL SALONS subcatalog.

Coppice Halifax.title: Softwater Pinwheel
Coppice Halifax.about: SOFTWATER PINWHEEL is a four-track extended play, plucked from the archives and mastered for a proper release. Four versions of the same piece, initially created using a Yamaha QY-70 in tandem with several other key pieces of hardware, including Korg ER-1 and Boss DR-550/660 drum machines, the Korg ES-1 sampler and a small array of Volca synthesizers, such as the Keys analog polysynth (which I no longer possess) and the Bass analog mono. Altogether, SOFTWATER recalls extended singles such as MARAIS, JEL GUN and aspects of the ANALOG BOTANY series. It conveys a subdued atmosphere of dub chords and spaced-out synth accompaniment over heavy subharmonic bass and rhythms that alternate between a Voigt-esque schaffel and a more precise minimal techno attitude. The first two tracks were recorded in January 2016, in the Botany Bay studio, while the third and fourth tracks were alternate approaches to the same pieces, laid to tape in 2017 after relocating to the White Pillar Workshop in Ohio. Special thanks is owed to Atoll Intercom Systems, who not only designed the beautiful and evocative cover image used here, but also assisted in the arrangement and final sequencing of this release.
Coppice Halifax.credits:
released March 5, 2021
            
            W/P by Brian Grainger. #1-2 recorded at Botany Bay, January 2016. #3-4 recorded at White Pillar, Summer 2017. Mastered by The Analog Botanist at White Pillar, March 2021. Photograph, design and sequencing assistance by Atoll Intercom Systems. This is Milieu Music number ABX117.  milieu-music.com   analogbotany.com

Coppice Halifax.title: Memory Maker [The Analog Botany Mixes]
Coppice Halifax.about: This album contains eight versions of material from the concurrent Milieu album Memory Maker, which offers up a new and unique audio format on clear plastic disks. The album was conceived and recorded entirely within the dream-state and projected telepathically onto the clear disks in realtime. When the decision was made to remix this strange audio, some transfiguration was necessary in order to facilitate a truly clear and deep CH sound, resulting in the manifestation of these equally mystical black plastic disks. The pandemic has made the world an increasingly strange place to live and make music in, so it follows that the impulses and ideas uncovered while asleep in that world would be just as alien and unfamiliar. You can read more about the tools and processes used to create these pioneering new works here:  milieumusic.bandcamp.com/album/memory-maker
Coppice Halifax.credits:
released April 1, 2021
            
            W/P by Brian Grainger. Recorded at White Pillar, March 2020, using source sound from Milieu's Memory Maker album in conjunction with the Invisible Digital Instrument Onboard Transport and the No-Fuss Telepathy methodology. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. Text and design by ABM&D. This is Milieu Music number MMAF02.  milieu-music.com   analogbotany.com  17463.space

Coppice Halifax.title: Halifaxian Cantos III
Coppice Halifax.about:
Premiering on the Deep Breakfast podcast series in Italy (  soundcloud.com/deepbreakfastseries/deep-breakfast-054-coppice-halifax  ) are new longform recordings by Coppice Halifax, for/from a series of works titled Halifaxian Cantos. As the title might imply, these pieces represent the wordless prose of the Halifaxian continent, intimate and minimalistic devotionals sung to the seasons, the sea and the stars beyond them. Coppice Halifax has long maintained an ethos of acting as Aquarius the water-bearer, bringing forth decorative vessels of elemental splendor for both sustenance and reflection, and these Cantos have taken shape via this same approach, using a near-generative process that deifies and transmutes orchestral provenance into the almost infinite. A microcosmic study in ambient techno, drone music and process-driven synthesis, Halifaxian Cantos further explore and christen the unmapped lands of the Halifaxian landscape, offering a recorded output that is both tranquil and evocative in their wake. Longtime CH listeners will appreciate noticeable references to Verdant Acre, Reflector, Ferrolog, Dripping Earth and the now-numerous Arborist's Excavations in these works. 



N.B. (3/3/21): This third volume of the Cantos continues the path charted by the first two, and in some ways, diverges a bit into Wagnerian abyssals that feel at times excessively dark and, only moments later, triumphant and beautiful. This may yet be a more divisive volume of the series, but much like things such as Verdant Acre or Dripping Earth before it, Halifaxian Cantos reflects the asymmetry and organic dissonance commonly found in the natural world, by using a process that attempts to transfigure existing compositions from Bach with a human touch, somewhere buried beneath all of the automation and generative effects. What this means is that, at a molecular level, all of the joy, the sadness and everything in between that exists within Bach's work is here amplified and elongated considerably, to be illustrated by massively deep trenches of isolation and depression, and unfathomably high peaks of white mountaintops kissed by sunshine, and titanic waves that carry us back and forth between the two on the currents of time and space.
Coppice Halifax.credits:
released March 5, 2021
            
            W/P by Brian Grainger. Arranged, generated, processed and recorded at White Pillar, Winter 2021. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. Text and design by ABM&D. This is Milieu Music number BWV-UE 0003, third in the Halifaxian Cantos subcatalog.  www.milieu-music.com  /  www.analogbotany.com

Coppice Halifax.title: Winter Arch
Coppice Halifax.about: Winter is a severe season, at least much more so than it was (or wasn't at all) in the subtropics of South Carolina. I often feel as if I've inherited the seasons themselves, living here in Ohio, and snow falling never fails to make me feel like I'm living in a fantasy world. Reeling from the joy of looking out of my windows and seeing blankets of white, I took the occasion to jam out some equally joyous and frenetic Halifaxian dance tracks. These two pieces manifested as Winter Arch and White Drum, and felt like the Winter answer to Autumn's Ferine Alembix, in how raw and huge they came out on the tape. They were a lot of fun, start to finish, and I didn't want to obsess too heavily over them, preferring instead to simply fire them off for Bandcamp Friday, mixer to table, smoke em if you've got em. These are electric and alive sessions, and hopefully convey some of the pent-up energy and excitement that I've been saving for live performances that could presumably happen after the pandemic recedes, and like Ferine Alembix, the grittiness and compressor-abuse present in these mixes recalls a very classic Coppice Halifax aesthetic, one I feel completely comfortable with whenever the occasion permits it. If there's been one good thing about staying inside for so long with this pandemic going around, it is that I have been justified in falling down my own creative rabbit hole even further, by virtue of having nowhere else to go anyway...so setting up elaborate roller coaster rides like these just to zoom through them over and over again all by myself isn't so much a depressing prospect as an immensely enthralling one. As my wife is often fond of quoting: "Can't go mad, ain't got time"
Coppice Halifax.credits:
released February 5, 2021
            
            W/P by Brian Grainger. Recorded at White Pillar, February 2021. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. Text and photography by ABM&D. This is Milieu Music number ABX115E.

Coppice Halifax.title: Dusty Acre
Coppice Halifax.about:
DUSTY ACRE offers up two Halifaxian reconstitutions of source material from Milieu's A DUSTY BOX OF OLD MEMORIES album, arranged during the remastering process in July of 2015. These pieces, not entirely distant or dissimilar to things like VERDANT ACRE or URCEOLATMOSPHERION, recall the tape-bleached Casio palette used on the original Milieu recordings, juxtaposed against a mutant-parametric drum kit and bassline, generated using various loopers and low-bit samplers at the time. Overgrown and wildly tangential, these sessions will appeal to fans of albums like A BLUE FUME, CORNUCOPIAD or ELUVIAN II. 



NOTE: For listeners looking to hear the entire remastered A DUSTY BOX OF OLD MEMORIES album, these two mixes are appended as a second disc in the limited edition 2xCD-R set, available at the Milieu page:  milieumusic.bandcamp.com/album/a-dusty-box-of-old-memories-expanded-remastered
Coppice Halifax.credits:
released December 4, 2020
            
            Written by Milieu. Remixed and produced by Coppice Halifax, July 2015, at Botany Bay, SC. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. Photograph by A.C. with post-processing by Brian. This is Milieu Music number AD18B.

Coppice Halifax.title: White Pillar X
Coppice Halifax.about:
Improvised and broadcast live on Twitch on the evening of February 15th, 2018, this final entry in the White Pillar series was originally shelved for possible release at another label, but given the circumstances of 2020 and the general landscape of many label operations right now, I've decided to just issue White Pillar X here. 



The entirety of the White Pillar sessions were informal and improvisational recordings that were designed for learning, growing, observing and adjusting to a new physical space after I relocated from the Botany Bay studio in the subtropics, to the titular new basement space in October of 2016. Six-hundred miles of distance, changes in barometric pressure, temperature, humidity, wind speed and elevation all factored into the music I'd make here, as did the new organizational workflow of having two six-foot long table tops to spread out all of my machines. It was nice to have a series of sessions that were only ever intended to explore the new spaces a bit, without any concerns over commercial viability or relationships to prior works, and somewhat ironically, the recordings themselves manifested as very cohesive dub techno pieces, a clear through-line able to be traced from WPW000 to WPW010 here. 



Sonically, there is a lot of analog synthesis and processing happening, with splashes of digital FX and some PCM drum sampling. You can hear a lot of my favorite romplers like the Boss DR-660 and Yamaha RY-20 taking precedence, as well as machines I did not possess until I relocated and had more tabletop space to use, such as the Korg MS-20 and Grass C-TCM. Everything is sequenced on the machines' internal sequencers themselves, no external MIDI brains or computer involvement whatsoever. For trainspotters who are interested in seeing the live session, the broadcast was captured and archived here:  youtu.be/iJ0DAGS4WD8



 Looking back on this session now, I find it immensely interesting, as the White Pillar studio has since evolved and rearranged itself several times over since it was generated. I enjoy a lot of the funky moments and I love hearing the Korg Volca Keys in a few lead moments, as this unit later burned out in an electrical storm and has not been replaced. White Pillar X is a solid dub techno monument in the CH continent, and a fitting end to the long-running series. 



**NOTE: In addition to White Pillar X being issued solo, I've assembled a 6xCD collector's edition box set that compiles all eleven WPW catalog releases, plus several alternative mixes and three previously unreleased takes. You can check that out here:
Coppice Halifax.credits:
released November 6, 2020
            
            W/P by Brian Grainger. Performed and recorded live at White Pillar Workshop, February 15th 2018. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. Photography by Brian, Dayton 2018. Text and design by ABM&D. This is Milieu Music number WPW010, the 10th and final release in the White Pillar catalog.  milieu-music.com   analogbotany.com

Coppice Halifax.title: Sea Leveler
Coppice Halifax.about:
In celebration of the reissue of 2008's long out of print drone-triptych POROUS VARIATIONS, I've revisited the session tapes and used some modern-age Halifaxian alchemy to render the woodsy resonations and monolithic bass down into so many grains of glittering sand that wash up on a familiar shore. Primarily sampling the POROUS VARIATIONS cut 'Sequoian', I felt compelled to process these old growths into sturdy stained boards, reassembled into a vessel that sets out to sea after the advancing ocean tide begins to subtract a little too much from the landscape. If none of this makes any sense, I can only apologize, because it all feels perfectly aligned in my mind's eye. Coppice Halifax as a project, even as a name, has always been meant to invoke the most vivid elements from oceanic and forestial locations, and something about working with POROUS VARIATIONS again felt very connected to that initial ethos. As you listen to this huge session, it should slowly become apparent that the towering trees and green canopies eventually and inevitably give way to rising sea levels, humidities, salty sunbeams rippling across bow and broken wave. It begins in the deep woods and ends adrift somewhere in the Atlantic. A truly liminal piece of work that could only ever exist between the two very different worlds of my work as Coppice Halifax, and my work under my birthname.



**NOTE: For listeners unfamiliar with the massive POROUS VARIATIONS album who wish to take the full trip, a special ltd. edition 4xCD-R box set, which includes this deep mix, awaits you here:  briangrainger.bandcamp.com/album/porous-variations-expanded-remastered
Coppice Halifax.credits:
released December 4, 2020
            
            Written by Brian Grainger. Remixed and produced by Coppice Halifax at White Pillar, Autumn 2020, using only the original session tapes from Porous Variations as source. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. Text and photography by ABM&D. This is Milieu Music number AD33B.  milieu-music.com   analogbotany.com

Coppice Halifax.title: Astral Salons [Phase 1]
Coppice Halifax.about:
Another year, another series, another branch in the long path of exploring my creative continents. 2021 brings us to ASTRAL SALONS, a nine-section series of monthly EP installments that land somewhere between STATIC PHARMING and SILHOUETTES, bridging the corporeal and the cosmic in concise twenty-minute jaunts that are designed to groove and meander in equal measure, and hopefully do not overstay their welcome. The digital 4x12" FERINE ALEMBIX could be seen as a precursor for this series, as those sessions put me back in the mood to produce an EP series again, and further, ASTRAL SALONS are not just informed by their more "modest" runtimes, but also a very fresh and unique approach to modulation, stereo panning and sonic depth-of-field that I've played with in the past, but haven't yet focused so completely upon until now. 



Paired with these sessions are nine Polaroids shot using expired film, on the day of the August 21st, 2017 total solar eclipse. I felt that these images were appropriate analogs for the concept of the series, being surrealist and psychedelic multi-layered pieces with deliberately lossy artifacting, overexposed processing and overlaps of FX processes in motion that leave "holes" in the sound field. The photographs are presented as they were developed, with only some contrasting and digital cleanup work done in post, again mirroring my studio process for the ASTRAL SALONS sessions.
Coppice Halifax.credits:
released January 31, 2021
            
            W/P by Brian Grainger. Recorded at White Pillar, January 2021. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. Text and photography by ABM&D. This is Milieu Music number PHASE 1, first in the ASTRAL SALONS subcatalog.

Coppice Halifax.title: White Pillar [Compleat Sessions]
Coppice Halifax.about:
After relocating my studio from Botany Bay in the subtropics of central South Carolina to a chilly basement nestled in a wind-swept Ohio valley, a decision was made (partially out of necessity) to create a path forward in the new space, christening it as I went, with recordings that were designed to explore the room, the new configuration of hardware, the possibilities in workflow and of course observe the myriad of ways that my creative impulses could be affected by differences in elevation, temperature, barometric pressure and humidity. 



In South Carolina, there is only ever one season - an endless Summer, a green Hell - but arriving in Ohio, it was immediately and abundantly clear how different everything felt. There was breeze, almost constantly, the grass was a finer texture than the severe jungle-blades in the south, and the seasons had phases that were pronounced and defined. Additionally, my new space was within relative proximity to things like NASA Glenn, the Serpent Mound and Wright-Patterson AFB (where they supposedly moved the Area 51 crash debris), and with my Deep Earth series already underway, it was suddenly within reach and consideration to commune with these things by way of radio bands and an invisible feeling in the air that was newness itself.



Although the White Pillar sessions were initially drafted as a somewhat experimental offshoot of Deep Earth, intended to be even more free-form than those recordings, existing only to serve the new studio space first and foremost, to highlight whatever strengths and weaknesses needed to now be accounted for, it soon became obvious to me that the studio's namesake catalog would be a cogent sound, singular and defined from moment to moment. In this way, it succeeded far beyond any of my preconceptions in presenting the shape of things to come. 



Sonically, the White Pillar sessions utilize a lot of live AM radio band reception, channeled through a number of FX devices both analog and digital, alongside improvisations conducted on a wide array of hardware, from analog synthesizers like the Arturia Microbrute and Korg MS-20 to digital rompler rhythm machines like the Boss DR-660 and Yamaha RY-20. More unique textural things entered the fray also, such as a fetal doppler, piezoelectric microphones attached to pipes in the basement's ceiling, walkie-talkie transmissions from my daughter's bedroom two floors above and even my then-recently acquired Grass Click-Tone Control Module, a piece of medical equipment that I repurposed into a tone generator. All of these things flowed into the veins of a Peavey FX2 24-channel mixing desk, christened "King Stevie" by none other than close friend and influence Stephen Hitchell (who was a guiding mentor in choosing the right mixer when I'd finally outgrown my Mackie), and manifested in deep shades of dub techno, ambient drifts, majestic hills and valleys of chord sweeps and thick, soil-caked rhythms. 



Many of these recordings not only served to outline what was possible in the new White Pillar studio space, but also presaged many of my generative processes and experiments that would go on to inform the assembly of my first modular system, the R-EW Audioholistics processing path. Listening back to the recordings now, I cannot think of a better method of breaking new ground in a new state, both mental and geographical, and I feel that the entire project holds together in extremely cohesive and enjoyable ways. 



This collection totals almost seven hours of material, and includes all ten numbered entries in the WPW catalog, the precursor EP WPW000, four alternative takes and three previously unreleased "Triadics" of Pillar Ø. Thirty tracks laid across six discs for a highly immersive experience.
Coppice Halifax.credits:
released November 6, 2020
            
            W/P by Brian Grainger. Recorded live at White Pillar Workshop, October 2016-February 2018, without the use of computers or overdubs. Hardware: Korg Volca Beats/Bass/Keys/Sample, Korg MS-20, Roland SH-32, Grass C-TCM, Arturia Microbrute, Boss DR-660, Yamaha RY-20, Unisonic MX-8888, augmented by Alesis Quadraverb, Pioneer SR202W, BBE Two Timer, Boss RV-3/SL-20, Moog MIDI MuRF/ringmod, Synthrotek PT2399, Ibanez PM7, channeled through a Peavey FX2x24 mixing desk. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. Photography by Brian, October 2016, Columbia SC. Text and design by ABM&D. Sticker printed by David Tagg in Atlanta GA. This is Milieu Music number WPW65437.  milieu-music.com   analogbotany.com

Coppice Halifax.title: Urth Redux [Volume 1]
Coppice Halifax.about:
As the outwardly expanding DEEP EARTH series soon enters its sixth consecutive year, I felt it was pertinent to look back and reorganize some of the earlier material into an accessible and affordable entry point for the series. The musical content of DEEP EARTH has always been leaning toward the experimental, but with feet mostly planted in the minimal techno and ambient worlds that Coppice Halifax tends to explore. As such, any of the first three years of DEEP EARTH are as appropriate to begin with, and that is why I will be offering these URTH REDUX assemblages. Each volume of URTH REDUX contains all twelve monthly installments of one year long leg of DEEP EARTH. Streamlined, efficient, free of any bonus outtakes or peripheral explorations or alternative realities bleeding through - this is DEEP EARTH distilled and concentrated, and packaged in a collectible set that will not break the bank. Each URTH REDUX set comes banded together as twelve separate discs in white jackets with title stickers on the front, and sometimes including the "secret messages" from first editions of these releases on the back, all held snugly together between two thick square matboard panels that are labeled and ink stamped. A huge amount of material, priced at a large discount, and offered without the need to subscribe to the full series.



For more information about DEEP EARTH as well as the perks of subscriptions:  malfokusita.bandcamp.com
Coppice Halifax.credits:
released December 4, 2020
            
            W/P by Brian Grainger. Recorded at Botany Bay, 2015-2016. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. Text and design by ABM&D. This is Milieu Music number UR001.  milieu-music.com   analogbotany.com

Coppice Halifax.title: Sacral Phases
Coppice Halifax.about:
SACRAL PHASES consists of two beatless pieces that manifested peripherally during the SILHOUETTES sessions earlier in the Summer. They reflect both the atmospheric texture of SILHOUETTES and the melodic provenance of STATUETTES, the latter being transfigured through my generative process to create the former. These two recordings were included only on a strictly limited edition of 8 copies (four numbered, and four 'artist print' copies) of the 12xCD-R deluxe boxed variant of SILHOUETTES, and now that this edition is sold out, I felt it was only fair to make SACRAL PHASES available publicly, since I am never interested in deliberately keeping material hard to obtain. Musically, they are deeply calming pieces that I find work well on their own, outside of being appended to SILHOUETTES, and recall aspects of Milieu's ongoing VIBRATELEPATHOS series (((  vibratelepathos.bandcamp.com  ))) in how they were created as well as their sonic personalities. 



NOTE: If you are one of the eight owners of the 12xCD-R SILHOUETTES set, please only purchase this release if you absolutely must own it. I am planning, subsequent to the SACRAL PHASES release, to send all eight of you free download codes to add this release to your collections. Your continued support is appreciated.
Coppice Halifax.credits:
released December 4, 2020
            
            W/P by Brian Grainger. Recorded at White Pillar, Summer 2020, using Milieu's STATUETTES albums as provenance, laid to tape tangentially during the SILHOUETTES sessions. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. Text and design by ABM&D. This is Milieu Music number ABX116A.  milieu-music.com   analogbotany.com 



 Special thanks to all of the members of the Milieu Music Fan Club at Patreon (  patreon.com/analogbotany  ). With their continued support, more music like this release can happen! At the present moment, the members of the Fan Club are: Burt T / Brian S / Jake P / Chris S / Tyler L / David HS / Peter H-B / Rik J / Jose AMS / Tarek E / Kevan F / Justin W / Michael R / JC Bastos / Helge J / Peter C / Alan A / Seth B / Daniel F / Joel B / Charlie 82 / Devin H / Mathieu L / Andy B / Francois H / Benoit P / Alex G / Rimas C / James S / Joseph S / Giovanni R / Gavin McF / Balz B / Juan D / Gavin C / David P / Andrew O'K / Peter T / Jona W / Alex B / Axl559 / Gordon C / Frank S V / Aba D O / Bernd H / Miles B / Tony S / Sean W / David A

Support deep electronic mining initiatives today:  malfokusita.bandcamp.com   vibratelepathos.bandcamp.com

Coppice Halifax.title: At Water's Edge
Coppice Halifax.about:
A deeply transfigurative excavation of my NOXIOUS VARIATIONS album, issued in 2009 under my birthname, rearranged here at the molecular level, from the skeletal, noisy and feedback-crusted experiments of the NOXIOUS sessions to a psychedelic evocation of a pastoral landscape, heavy with humidity and Southern sunlight. Primarily sourced from the NOXIOUS piece 'At Forest's Edge, Water Laps Over The Rocks', this expansive reinterpretation goes through several phases of crumbling dub techno chords, long bent lines of something resembling a synthesizer lead and many different shades and amalgams of both, with all elements in some type of process or movement between poles for the duration. A vibrant piece of ambient techno that recalls many of the textural ideas that Coppice Halifax as a project was designed to explore, and a lush counterpoint to the wild and overgrown images of the natural world at play on NOXIOUS VARIATIONS.



**NOTE: For listeners unfamiliar with the NOXIOUS VARIATIONS album who wish to take the full trip, a special ltd. edition 2xCD-R box set, which includes this deep mix, awaits you here:  briangrainger.bandcamp.com/album/noxious-variations-expanded-remastered
Coppice Halifax.credits:
released December 4, 2020
            
            Written by Brian Grainger. Remixed and produced by Coppice Halifax, Autumn 2020, using only source material from the Noxious Variations master recordings. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. This is Milieu Music number AD56B. Photography and text by ABM&D.  milieu-music.com   analogbotany.com

trackinfo.title: Brian Grainger - At Forest's Edge, Water Laps Over The Rocks [Coppice Halifax Transfiguration]

Coppice Halifax.title: Silhouettes II
Coppice Halifax.about:
Following the publication of the first half of the expansive Silhouettes session in September, the second half arrives just in time to close the book on 2020. With another ten Umbral Phases, Silhouettes II continues and concludes the bridge built between Milieu's Statuettes recordings and the Halifaxian Cantos, and establishes a unique through-line between the two very different projects...although these sessions happened so easily and naturally that I do wonder how much I was "establishing" anything, instead merely illuminating something that was already there to begin with. 



Like the prior ten Phases, these variations mutate and transfigure only a few simple rhythmic and melodic elements into whole new soundworlds, recalling my work ethic on prior CH monuments such as Dripping Earth and Night's Moisture. Silhouettes is a deceptively minimal collection of sounds, and most if not all of the variance that can be observed between Phases is owed to the fact that each session's tonal content (minus a bass monosynth) is derived completely from the original tape masters for a different Statuettes piece. With those shapes aligned and established, the rest of the changes from Phase to Phase were topographical in nature - a BPM shift, a bass line that only ever fills in empty spaces, textural alterations on drum parts and real-time modulation of certain effects processors. The result is, hopefully a set of recordings that feels complete and linear but also manages to offer diverse moods and atmospheric conditions. 



NOTE: As with the first Silhouettes set, there are two editions: A 10xCD-R bagged set which is a slightly larger run and priced more moderately, and a deluxe 12xCD-R boxed set that contains two additional sessions (Auroral Phase I & II) not present in other editions, with a shorter pressing run (a numbered set of four copies, and four more "Artist's Proof" copies for latecomers), offering a special option for collectors.
Coppice Halifax.credits:
released December 4, 2020
            
            W/P by Brian Grainger. Recorded at White Pillar Workshop, Summer 2020, using Milieu's Statuettes recordings and session materials alongside a Korg ES-1, Memphis Blue Beat, Behringer MS-1 and the R-EW modular processing path. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. Design and text by ABM&D. This is Milieu Music number ASH0006, 6th issuance in the Ashcan subcatalog.  milieu-music.com   analogbotany.com 



 Many thanks to the members of the Milieu Music Fan Club at Patreon and the subscribers at Deep Earth and Vibratelepathos - Without your support, things such as this may not exist!

Coppice Halifax.title: An Extract Of Keystone Flowers
Coppice Halifax.about:
A Halifaxian transfiguration of "Shimmering Skull Raga" from my White Kingdoms album, produced and published under my birthname. This mix was drafted for the occasion of the 10th anniversary expanded reissue of White Kingdoms, and is being made available digitally by itself for listeners who do not wish to buy a deluxe multi-disc edition in order to obtain a new CH recording. It was created using the original four-track session tapes from White Kingdoms as the sole audio source, and is in alignment with the many prior CH remixes of Milieu and BG recordings, previously collected as Arborist's Excavations, that appear on the Arboreal Digest reissue catalog entries.



To purchase this mix, as well as the expanded White Kingdoms album, on a 3xCD-R set, please visit the Brian Grainger Bandcamp page:  briangrainger.bandcamp.com/album/white-kingdoms-expanded-reissue

Photography by Brian, Foxhill 2009. Interpolation and text by ABM&D. Coppice Halifax.title: Ferine Alembix [Cide B]
Coppice Halifax.about: Hourly, nightly, I return to my ritual of sifting, considering, reshaping, mis-remembering, recontextualizing. FERINE ALEMBIX are sessions of burnt out elemental recall, doused in smoke, urgent crusts of Halifaxian tectonics thrust ever upward. What does this mean? What does anything ever mean? In the green face of the tree-lined valley I laugh and exhale and spit, Earth to Earth, returning, remembering, reconsidering. Fingers dirty with the thick resins of porch perspectives. A chair beside a window, looking out into the negotiated and acceptable overgrowths in a picturesque neighborhood street. For a moment, which could itself be many moments, years and universes zoomed in upon with the scrutin-eye of vaporized gods, the forest returns, blooms and leaves and stalks defiantly resistant of change and human hands, mocking and refuting the oblong vessels, orange inside like a candlelit coffin, welcoming you and I as guests in this great opened house. I laugh again, and make a joke, but neither of us can hear it as my words are swallowed up by a swirling, expanding breath of forestial celebration. Lungs full of wind, stars peeking out from behind clouds like some sea-sprayed beach above our heads. Another night, another dream, another alter to throw ourselves upon in wild delight. The curtains of evening are drawn across the landscape and beneath these canopies we melt, rendered down to sweet oils and quiet pigments, a vibrant pool of lucid navigation that we'll swim up to the surface of tomorrow, tomorrow, tomorrow, barely remembering.
Coppice Halifax.credits:

            W/P by Brian Grainger. Coppice Halifax.title: Silhouettes
Coppice Halifax.about:
After the years of work that resulted in two volumes of ambient compositions called STATUETTES, the curiosity to explore these recordings at the molecular level became too much to resist, and several different tangential sessions took place wherein the Statuettes material was melted down and reprocessed through several digital and analog systems, generative modular paths and FX processors, and used in performative ways reminiscent of the HALIFAXIAN CANTOS recordings. Casting shadows from the objects and structures built on STATUETTES, these SILHOUETTES are new lands and weather systems that recall their far off provenance alongside a Korg ES-1 sampler, a Memphis Blue Beat drum machine and a Behringer MS-1 analog monosynth. 



These recordings were originally drafted simply for the pleasure of doing them, to satisfy impulses and curiosities that naturally spring up around my work as I close in on completing different projects, but I've now decided to collect them, gloss them over with a nice cozy mastering pass and release them here in an effort to raise a bit of cash for a new modular synthesizer case, as I've already outgrown my first two cases. Due to this, SILHOUETTES will only be produced in a physical edition of 10 copies, unless/until more copies are necessary.



NOTE: The special "boxed" edition of SILHOUETTES contains two additional discs of material - SACRAL PHASE I & II - sidereal recordings that were neither wholly separated from the recording process nor completely in line with the main "phases"
Coppice Halifax.credits:
released September 19, 2020
            
            W/P by Brian Grainger. Recorded at White Pillar Workshop, Summer 2020, using Milieu's Statuettes recordings and session materials alongside a Korg ES-1, Memphis Blue Beat, Behringer MS-1 and the R-EW modular processing path. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. Design and text by ABM&D. This is Milieu Music number ASH0005, 5th issuance in the Ashcan subcatalog.  milieu-music.com   analogbotany.com 



 Many thanks to the members of the Milieu Music Fan Club at Patreon and the subscribers at Deep Earth and Vibratelepathos - Without your support, things such as this may not exist!

Coppice Halifax.title: Silverine [Milkwhite Mixes]
Coppice Halifax.about:
The MILKWHITE MIXES, the second of two remix variants for SILVERINE, containing mixes produced in a more ambient techno/braindance/IDM vein by several close friends who are themselves influences on my work. Appearing here, and continuing the mutation of SILVERINE via their own unique approaches to my studio's sound palette, are...



ZWEI KREISE, previously known as AXS, providing the most counterpoint interpretation of the cut yet, recalling classic records from DIN, MAS and other early 00s imprints...



SUBSTAK, reprising his appearance on the BLUESHADE MIXES, offering a beatless and serene view of the eroded keyboard melodies in the original, here isolated and beautifully undisturbed...



THEE WOLF CODE, aka MOSCA, rinsing the sample pack in a short but effective jungle mix, cleansing the palate with brute force...



ARBEE, mulching and modulating the source material via a custom-build modular synthesizer, which occasionally drips out plumes of inky sound, dubbed bass and a very restrained groove...



DUSKLARK, aka FOREST SATELLITE, transfiguring the chords and bass of the original into something wholly his own, a wistful bus ride with rainy windows, while you miss someone you're far away from...



COPPICE HALIFAX, closing the curtain on the entire affair with a fifteen-minute bedroom carpeted mix that wouldn't be out of place on MILKWHITE PLASTIC GALAXY MAKER, Q TRAX or PINK/PLASTIC ACRE...



...PROGRAM REPEATS ON SIDE ONE / BLUESHADE MIXES... 



coppicehalifax.bandcamp.com/album/silverine-blueshade-mixes

Coppice Halifax.title: Silverine [Blueshade Mixes]
Coppice Halifax.about:
The BLUESHADE MIXES, one of two remix variants for SILVERINE, containing mixes produced in a more deep techno vein by several close friends who are themselves influences on my work. Appearing here, and continuing the mutation of SILVERINE via their own unique approaches to my studio's sound palette, are...



LAMONT KOHNER, aka ELECTRICWEST and ELUDER, with two heavyweight dubs, built for bong hits in the cushy backseat of a discreetly parked car...



MONO PENINSULA, aka PHOTOPHOB, distilling the humidity down into a reggae-soaked dub that nods to Rhythm & Sound in a welcome reconstruction...



JAYMON, member of NEMO & JAYMON, the German woodcentric crew at FOREST ROOTS, with a buoyant reprise that brings to mind sunlight dappling on bark as the leaves sway in a light breeze, vaguely shifting under the movements of birds and other forest wildlife...



DOWNSCOPE with a machine-pulsed sub-bass mass of pistons and valves, spattered with oil, pulverizing raw materials into dust and fluid runoff, reconstituted for your pleasure...



SUBSTAK, pulling everything on the faders so far back that only an austere skeleton of the track remains, wandering in a bleak landscape like a bereft lost soul as storms approach overhead...



THE NAUTILUS PROJECT, the second half of NEMO & JAYMON at FOREST ROOTS, scanning the pastoral landscape in his landing craft and detecting habitable conditions with which to enjoy a nature documentarian excursion...



JAMES SHAIN, sometime operator of COLD FICTION who also records as DEEPWARMTH, discarding all semblance of rhythm and structure in favor of a lush 13-minute beatless sound field...



...PROGRAM CONTINUES ON SIDE TWO / MILKWHITE MIXES... 



coppicehalifax.bandcamp.com/album/silverine-milkwhite-mixes

Coppice Halifax.title: Silverine
Coppice Halifax.about:
SILVERINE came into existence in the same way things like RIVER TABLEAUX, RAFT, VALLEYFOAM and ICED WHITE did - drafted as sessions of deep techno destined for issuance at Cold Fiction's recurring Futur[e]cho compilation series. To date, CH has been a participant in all ten volumes of this series, and the tenth volume is what conjured SILVERINE from the dim lamps, cable nests and warm machines in the White Pillar Workshop earlier this year. 



This release contains the full SILVERINE session, with all four of the progressively deeper and more mutated versions of the cut, filling out sixty-six minutes of dub techno that feels like it belongs somewhere in the spectrum of sound between VERDANT ACRE, URCEOLATMOSPHERION and LEAF CLOAK. Perceptive listeners will recognize certain production tricks and even palette selections that were utilized in the SILVERINE session, such as the "burnt chord" sound that originated with LEAF CLOAK. 



SUPPORT COLD FICTION'S COMPILATION HERE, WHICH INCLUDES MIX #1 OF SILVERINE:  cfmlabel.bandcamp.com/album/futur-e-cho-2020
Coppice Halifax.credits:
released September 4, 2020
            
            W/P by Brian Grainger. Recorded at White Pillar, April 2020. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. Design and text by ABM&D. This is Milieu Music number ABX112.  milieu-music.com   analogbotany.com

Coppice Halifax.title: Audioholistics
Coppice Halifax.about:
AUDIOHOLISTICS was a live set that was performed on March 20, 2020, shortly after the pandemic began. It was intended to be a live event at a coffee shop in Yellow Springs, Ohio, but after public safety became a concern, the show was canceled and the decision was made to broadcast the set live on Twitch instead. 



Sonically, the set was designed to be the live iteration of the style of CH recordings like MILKWHITE PLASTIC GALAXY MAKER and PINK/PLASTIC ACRE, with elements that focus on melodic braindance and ambient techno from the mid 1990s, with obvious reference points to things like Warp's Artificial Intelligence series or the early Rephlex catalog. In addition to this, there are still moments of a more "modern" CH sound, with aspects of dub techno (via the ANALOG BOTANY series or PAWLEYS ISLAND) present alongside some drone synthesis that recalls things like LEAF CLOAK or even STATIC PHYSICS. 



After finishing the live set, the going idea was to stash the recordings in favor of sitting down for a few proper studio sessions and building out individual tracks using many of the sections, to perhaps assemble a full album with them. As time went on, however, and I revisited the recordings of the set itself (and two rehearsals that were also recorded), I discovered that I much preferred these sections of melody and groove in their momentary development, within the momentum of the live set itself, rather than as isolated compositions. They felt more purposeful as part of the whole process and performance, so individualizing them felt unnecessary. 



So I've finally sat down with these recordings and done my best to master them, which is always a challenge with translating live recordings from things that are designed to work in a live experience versus things that are meant to be studio creations. The full set from March 20th is included here, in both indexed (separated) form and as an unedited single file (which is available as a courtesy to paying supporters here), and this set is augmented by the presence of two earlier rehearsals, which themselves highlight how much of AUDIOHOLISTICS was pattern-based improvisation and not structured or planned. The first rehearsal was a room recording, informally made, so the audio quality is not optimal, but this recording was included here to give a better indication of what it sounded like as it happened in an acoustic space, and not too dissimilar from what it may have sounded like at the Yellow Springs coffee shop, if that were to have happened. The second rehearsal was recorded from Twitch, to test volume and bass levels in OBS (the software used to organize live streaming) and to make certain compensations after taking into consideration the compression and loss that inevitably occurs when you stream audio online. 



All three sets are unique and similar in many ways, and work together to form a cohesive picture of both Coppice Halifax as a live action, and the small array of drum machines, samplers and synthesizers (dubbed the Microbotany rig) used to convey it.
Coppice Halifax.credits:
released September 4, 2020
            
            W/P by Brian Grainger. Recorded live at White Pillar Workshop, March 18-20, 2020 using Korg Volca Beats/Bass/Sample/FM/Modular/Kick, KP-2 Kaoss Pad, R-EW modular system and an Optimus SSM-1750 mixer. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. Text and photography by ABM&D. This is Milieu Music number ABX114.  milieu-music.com   analogbotany.com  Special thanks to everyone who attended the original broadcast.

Coppice Halifax.title: Opal (Droned)
Coppice Halifax.about: Originally recorded at Botany Bay between 2012-2013, this extended and dubbed out version of Opal (from Pacific Opal Hex) found a small release in Autumn 2019 as a bonus disc with a limited edition of the 8xCD Deep Works retrospective box set. With the pandemic now sweeping the globe and digital audio taking precedence over physical ritual out of sheer necessity, I have decided to offer Opal (Droned) as a digital release in the name of accessibility. It comes at an apt moment, as the Pacific Opal Hex album is also finally available on the CH Bandcamp platform, so between these two releases, there are now two full hours plus of tropical dubby mid-tempo deep listening. Both the P.O.H. album and this version of Opal exist within the same universe as Ocean Lion, High Hawaiian Fog and Tigress, so for listeners who enjoy those recordings, this is a trip well worth taking.
Coppice Halifax.credits:

Coppice Halifax.title: Ebleco / Possibility
Coppice Halifax.about:
...EARTH 52 in YEAR FIVE of the DEEP EARTH series...



La tondado de tuŝo, eksplodanta en ĉiuj direktoj sen zorgo aŭ konsekvenco. Fragmentoj de tio, kio estis difinitaj sekcioj de la memo, eksplodis en ŝtormon de statika kaj bruo. Ĉiu peco, ĉiu ero, malgranda universo plena de novaj steloj, novaj sunoj, blindigantaj kaj vivaj. Bruligitaj tra tavolo post tavolo, paralelaj realaĵoj kuniĝis en cindron.
