Coppice Halifax.title: Cmx XI
Coppice Halifax.about:
The eleventh volume of the mountainous Cmx series, which collects Coppice Halifax remix works and sequences them into coherent album-like entities. This volume opens with a unique track commissioned by Always Human Tapes for their concept-compilation cassette "Mount Real - Music To The Motion Picture" - bearing the name Lioness, this piece meanders and slowly blooms across almost nine minutes, and is built almost entirely out of samples from a number of vinyl sides from Loretta Lynn, Simon & Garfunkel, M.I.A. and Buffalo Springfield.



Following Lioness is a previously unreleased remix for Cetra, a Scottish musician perhaps better known as Mosca, which undulates with heavy synth chords and a Kompakt-like schaffel beat. The club vibe fully emerges on the "Circuit Burst" mix of Nntblst's Risset Overtones, a heavy dancefloor locomotive, bubbling over with white noise sweeps, spastic arps and hollowed out acid bass. After the workout is over, the chillout tent centerpiece Screener36 remix creeps in - sounding perhaps closer to early Aphex Twin than any other CH track to date. In the wake of the ambient techno bliss-out, the eleven minute "Live In The Dark Room" mix for Oxynucid's acid techno romp subtly invades the space, stripping back Oxynucid's harsh analog arps and pounding rhythms and melting them down into a smooth smoky dub. With nowhere left to go, the bottom drops out with a 17 minute Magic Arrows remix, swirling and psychedelic with spattered guitars and clouds of melody everywhere, until a slow tropical bassline anchored to a head-nod break drives us home. This closing piece should also not-so-delicately hint at what is to be expected from Peppermint Carousels, the soon to be debuted collaboration between Magic Arrows and Coppice Halifax. 



Altogether, a vibrant trip through sound fields both Halifaxian and foreign, which is what the Cmx albums continue to so effectively communicate. Remixing remains one of the most stimulating challenges for my studio, and I'm always content to hear the returns this series yields over the years.
Coppice Halifax.credits:

Coppice Halifax.title: Cmx X [Remix Appendix]
Coppice Halifax.about:
Fittingly, alongside the 10th anniversary VAPORIZED FOREST INDEX album, we've also arrived at the tenth volume of the Cmx remix catalog. Considering this, it only felt appropriate to use this volume to make a counterpart for V.F.I., highlighting some of my favorite CH remixes from the last decade. 



Remixes for many other producers are often seen as trivial, promotional things, something you do to fill out a single or try and appeal to a club-going contingent with music that might otherwise stay out of such a setting. For me, remixing has always been one of my favorite studio activities, a way to momentarily see how sharp you can get with a single track, and someone else's source material. I have taken a more challenging approach to remixes as well, in that I do not use any of my own sounds in the tracks I produce - only things present in the original artist's piece. This process means a constant learning curve with sound design and FX processing, as well as creative mixing and sequencing work, in order to create a mix that is both faithful to the original music and adherent to my own sonic principles, and what I'd like to say in that moment. You might think such a stance would yield less melodic results, but in that case it becomes the opposite, most of the time - in becoming so intimate with the source sounds, new melodies and chord progressions are exhumed and an honest, valid reinterpretation of someone else's composition takes place. 



So for Cmx X, I picked seventeen of my favorite remixes, and with some preparatory work, I performed and recorded a DJ set using only those pieces. A constantly flowing and fluctuating seamless collection of all kinds of techno, ambient and braindance mixes, psychedelic and focused on the groove. With this, I offer a 10th anniversary Remix Appendix, and raise my glass to all of the many producers I've produced mixes for: Here's to ten more years of Coppice Halifax transmutations!
Coppice Halifax.credits:

Coppice Halifax.title: Hightide Crush
Coppice Halifax.about:
The third and final single from/for the Milieu & Coppice Halifax triple-album SUN CAST lands in the form of a Coppice Halifax tableaux. Presenting the opening cut on the second side of Sun Cast, Hightide Crush instead leads the listener down a different path, winding through more psychedelic smears of ambient techno, oceanic overexposure, tropical gloss and mid-fi mindmusic.



Essentially a full album of material that, for runtime and sequencing reasons, was left off the primary release. In some respects, the supporting material issued here is a softer approach to that tape-worn Halifaxian sound (found elsewhere on Ocean Lion, Pawleys Island and High Hawaiian Fog), whereas the second Sun Cast side presents a more aggressive tack - well, about as aggressive as 30-minute stoned and droned beach jams can get. A fitting encore to the massive Sun Cast trip, which is now over - or is it? 



Additionally, a video has been assembled for Hightide Crush, and you can watch it here:  youtu.be/cqAcVjgIxDk

Coppice Halifax.title: Window Cill
Coppice Halifax.about: Recorded in August 2016, right before I moved 600 miles from the subtropics, Window Cill was essentially the first take of the composition that would become Cillage on the CH section of the Sun Cast triple-album. While it conveys a totally different soundworld, melodically, one can see parallels in my producer's approach, with the long slow burn of chopped breaks building up, swirling chords coating the rhythm like a psychedelic fog and an elasticizing of time to further disorient the listener. In the end, it was redone entirely with a larger focus on the orchestral sampling that fills out Cillage, and this cut was left off of both Sun Cast and the subsequent singles due to its considerable length. Finally, Spring has arrived in the valley and Window Cill feels like the perfect thing to cast out into the air. This is one to be taken with you when you go, and played as loud as possible.
Coppice Halifax.credits:
released March 27, 2019
            
            W/P by Brian Grainger. Recorded at Botany Bay, August 2016. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. Text and photography by ABM&D. This is Milieu Music number MML133.

Coppice Halifax.title: 333/SOL
Coppice Halifax.about: As with the first two volumes of Solus recordings, Solus 3 has generated a companion release of alternate versions. Transfiguring Solus 3 into five totally different macrocosms of sonic space, 333/SOL fulfills the second aspect of the Solus ethos: Using only the singular source of the original recording to isolate and arrange new tracks, thereby utilizing the atmospheric content as a primary "lead" voice, despite the fact that very little emphasis has been placed on the creation of those sounds. This process allows subconscious design decisions to bubble up to the top, inevitably turning out unique and mutant music that is adherent to no real template or convention. 333/SOL is, topically speaking, a thick and organic techno record that dips its toe into drone and dub pools with total alien indifference. It would likely appeal to listeners who enjoyed albums like Chloroformic Forests, Photovoltaic Fragments, Somx, Cornucopiad and Eluvian II, and feels perfectly suited to the current chilly Autumn that's blowing through the Miami River valley.
Coppice Halifax.credits:
released November 21, 2018
            
            W/P by Brian Grainger. Recorded at White Pillar Workshop, November 2018. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. Design and text by ABM&D. This is Milieu Music number MML132.

Coppice Halifax.title: Arbaro Liberigo
Coppice Halifax.about: Arbaro Liberigo is a monument that exists in two worlds - the first being the Deep Earth universe, where it bears the previously mentioned name, the second being the Forest Roots universe, somewhere deep in the woods of Germany, where it has been christened by carving the name Forest Liberation into a thick tree trunk. This mammoth piece of psychedelic techno has been constructed by Nemo (aka The Nautilus Project) & Jaymon, using the entirety of the first year of Deep Earth's catalog as sound source, along with various devices from the Forest Roots studio and field recordings Nemo & Jaymon have captured in their extensive travels. It represents a true meeting of the minds, coalescing like a gigantic fog that hangs above South Carolina and Germany in tandem, and it also begins a Deep Earth catalog subset called Ripetis, or "Reiterated", which will serve as a vessel for Deep Earth reconstructions, remix works and excavations by external producers and studios.
Coppice Halifax.credits:
released May 31, 2016
            
            Written by Coppice Halifax. Remixed, produced and liberated by Nemo & Jaymon. Nemo & Jaymon appear on Deep Earth courtesy of Forest Roots, DE. Mastered by Forest Roots. Cover photography by Brian Grainger. This is Milieu Music number [RIPETIS 1]. © + ℗ Milieu Music & Forest Roots, 2016.

trackinfo.title: Deep Earth [Forest Liberation By Nemo & Jaymon]

Coppice Halifax.title: Alkemiisto
Coppice Halifax.about: The second release in the RIPETIS / REITERATED catalog of remixes and reconfigurations is ALKEMIISTO, a nine-track collection of selected remix approaches to Deep Earth by five of the most talented musicians I have the pleasure to know. Zwei Kreise, known previously as Axs, appears twice with a beat-based mix of Vintro and a beatless mix of Malaperis. Two of the denser mixes on ALKEMIISTO come from aural sculptor Arjen Schat, also known as Ohrwert. Fah appears here under his less-used Ambigen moniker, contributing two atmospheric pieces created with his custom-designed generative ambient software. Perhaps the most conventional sounding of all the mixes is the EARTH 4 reconstitution Cielarkus, courtesy of The Green Kingdom, while the album closes with a nearly half-hour excursion into Vintro by Orson Throb. An appropriate counterpoint to the year's fruits in the series, and a solid full-length album of deep and experimental techno works by some of the best minds in the market today.
Coppice Halifax.credits:
released May 31, 2016
            
            Written by Brian Grainger. Produced and remixed by the credited artists. Mastered by The Analog Botanist at Botany Bay, May 2016. Cover photography by Brian Grainger. This is Milieu Music number RIPETIS 2. © + ℗ Milieu Music, 2016. All rights reserved.

Coppice Halifax.title: Okazi [Enkorpigita]
Coppice Halifax.about: For the fifth issue of the RIPETIS / REITERATED catalog, a surprising record emerges from the hands of both Coppice Halifax and COAL, who you may recall from his 20+ minute "Poisoned Acre" reconstruction for the recent Verdant Compost set. COAL and CH embark on an improvisational live session, rearranging and remixing OKAZI at the molecular level. The session yielded five distinct sections, culled from a very stream of consciousness performance process. The album moves through waves of drone, thick delay-spattered dub rhythms, pulses of bass textures and floor stomping techno, finishing with a lengthy meandering suite of ambient pings and resonant filter surfing. Part live perfomance, part remix, this "embodied" version of Okazi pairs well with the second year of the DEEP EARTH series.
Coppice Halifax.credits:
released July 12, 2017
            
            "Okazi" originally written and produced by Brian Grainger. Remixed live and produced by Coppice Halifax & COAL. Recorded Summer 2017 at White Pillar Workshop, using 3x Moogerfoogers, Korg Volca Beats, BBE Two Timer, Nady MM-14FX, Pioneer S202W, Alesis Quadraverb and Peavey FX2 hybrid mixing desk. COAL appears courtesy of Boiler Room Sound. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. This is Milieu Music number [RIPETIS 5].

Coppice Halifax.title: Substak Procesis 1
Coppice Halifax.about: The third issue in the RIPETIS / REITERATED series comes in two halves. Two volumes of Deep Earth remixes and reconstructions by the prolific Kostas Staikos, known better to the listening world as SUBSTAK. These 11 pieces are both subtle and drastic, sometimes shifting the rhythmic emphasis around, or coaxing out different harmonies with filters, and other times being completely mutated in Kostas' hands. Altogether they represent a very hi-fi listening experience, superb on headphones and heavy duty sound systems that can convey deep bass without distortion.
Coppice Halifax.credits:
released June 7, 2016

Coppice Halifax.title: Substak Procesis 3
Coppice Halifax.about: An unexpected set of five remixes by Substak, of EARTH 18 & 19. Substak previously contributed two volumes of Deep Earth remix works at the end of Year One, providing even more subharmonic and alien perspectives for the already disconnected electronics. PROCESIS 3 is no exception, bearing two slow-mo readings of ERO and three mutations of MALPLENA. A welcome counterpoint to the recent crop of Deep Earth excavations.
Coppice Halifax.credits:
released March 5, 2017
            
            Written by Brian Grainger / Produced & remixed by Substak. Recorded in Greece, March 2017. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. Many thanks to K.S. for producing these versions and for allowing Milieu Music to issue them.

Coppice Halifax.title: Aeriformic Forests
Coppice Halifax.about: Aeriformic Forests is a massive, undulating tapestry of sound, recorded during the Static Pharming sessions earlier in the year. A lengthy excursion into vaguely-rhythmic ambient dub, comprised of dozens of different tape loops and synth layers that meander around the stereo field, sporadically evaporating and then dripping back down on the humming bass foundation like rain. Walls of translucent light overlap to form floating pools of colors, while the womblike percussion isn't in a hurry to go anywhere. In this way, A.F. is simply and literally a document of Static Pharming - music created for aesthetic and impressionist values, rather than compositional movement. Wallpaper music for the dub techno crowd, you could say, and not too distantly related to other CH works such as Reflector or some of the Verdant Acre recordings. While this recording is available as a bonus disc inside the 5xCD Static Pharming: Year One box set, it has been made available here in a singular edition for the listeners who have already purchased all of the Static Pharming material separately.
Coppice Halifax.credits:
released December 30, 2013
            
            W/P by Coppice Halifax. Recorded at Botany Bay, October 2013. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. This is Milieu Music number RX78B.

Coppice Halifax.title: Eluvian
Coppice Halifax.about: Eluvian is the 15th Static Pharming EP, built entirely out of field recordings. Woodside trains, rocks in mud and fireworks coalesce together through a Halifaxian sound design that pieces together an alien obelisk out of thin air. Organic and overgrown, but still totally rhythmic and faithful to the dub techno template.
Coppice Halifax.credits:
released March 3, 2014
            
            W/P by Coppice Halifax. Recorded at Botany Bay, February 2014. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. This is Milieu Music number RX15, 15th in the ongoing Static Pharming series.

Coppice Halifax.title: Outpost
Coppice Halifax.about: The second EP of the 2014 Static Pharming series is the open skied sonic expanse Outpost. Rolling grey chords mutated from Bedrich Smetana's orchestral impressionism pour out from heavy clouds and distant thunder, and a lurching rhythm appears beneath the shadows. Slowly, the desert sky opens up and cold rain touches down on the cracked sepia rock and sand. In an abandoned building not far away, a broken radio receiver spills static and fuzz into the airwaves, and a pronounced kick drum drops from the storm, using a single note of bass as its counterpoint. By the end of this excursion, the washes of rainy sheets of sad string drones hit a critical mass, and a sparse organ melody appears inside the wetness, bringing the sunshine out and driving the grey clouds away.
Coppice Halifax.credits:
released February 2, 2014
            
            W/P by Coppice Halifax. Recorded at Botany Bay, February 2014. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. This is Milieu Music number RX14, and 14th in the Static Pharming series.

Coppice Halifax.title: Gemstones In Ice
Coppice Halifax.about:
It isn't often I run a year-long series, and finish it, and then decide to keep going. Usually, I feel that an EP a month for a year is enough to really rinse out whatever idea I had at the beginning, and that maybe I will revisit it later on once I get some new ideas to apply to the project. Static Pharming is the first series I've started that I felt was only beginning to come into its own, and pick up proper momentum, by the time the 12th month rolled in. Perhaps it is the ever-expanding and tangential aspect of Coppice Halifax as a project now, perhaps I'm just addicted to getting lost in my own forests. So, with RX13, I'm raising my glass to all of you - here's to another year of Pharming!



Gemstones In Ice, as RX13, is a vibrant piece that was equally inspired by the winter cold and by the brilliant cv313 material that my friend Mr. Hitchell was sharing with me when I recorded it. Romping drums, copious amounts of white noise and delay artifacts, heavy use of filters and reverbs and of course thick bass figures that help punctuate the motorik rhythm. It's a feelgood slice of Analog Botany that is meant to jump start the second year of Static Pharming in a playful way. Press play, open your ears and let it wrap around you!
Coppice Halifax.credits:
released January 17, 2014
            
            W/P by Coppice Halifax. Recorded at Botany Bay, January 2014. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. This is Milieu Music number RX13, and 13th in the Static Pharming series.

Coppice Halifax.title: High Lights
Coppice Halifax.about: Somewhere between things like Verdant Acre and High Hawaiian Fog sits High Lights, the 18th EP in the Static Pharming series. Exploring the sadder side of ambient techno, High Lights focuses on the slow expansion and contraction of orchestral tape loops, ghosting over a subtle dubby rhythm and bass section. String sections play blue notes endlessly into a space echo chamber, while singled out violin leads wrap like thin wire around wooden barrels, floating out to sea long after the ship that carried them went to sleep beneath the waves.
Coppice Halifax.credits:
released June 13, 2014
            
            W/P by Brian Grainger. Recorded at Botany Bay, Summer 2014. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. This is Milieu Music number RX18, and 18th in the ongoing Static Pharming series.

Coppice Halifax.title: Cloudburst
Coppice Halifax.about: For RX17, the Static Pharming series produces Cloudburst, an overcast piece that layers together cloudy synth drones and tape-saturated bass. Growing gradually more misty and humidified, Cloudburst eventually reveals throbbing rhythmic shapes inside the haze that emerge with bright colors and an undeniable house-inflected groove.
Coppice Halifax.credits:
released May 17, 2014
            
            W/P by Coppice Halifax. Recorded at Botany Bay, April 2014. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. This is Milieu Music number RX17, and 17th in the ongoing Static Pharming series.

Coppice Halifax.title: Voltaic
Coppice Halifax.about: Orange canyon walls of weathered stone, warm with sun. Steep faces of rock surrounded on all sides by a calm blue ocean. Several other small islands are visible nearby, all connected via metal rail bridges. Further off in the distance, a storm begins to gather, prompting you to take shelter in one of several strange looking metallic hemispheres. Realizing there is no power to any of the machines, you begin the slow task of working out some repairs. Your search for replacement parts leads you to a massive airship, which only needs electricity to provide passage away from the remote island. Continuing your effort, you find a small dimly lit cave area with some workbenches, tools and - best of all - blueprints. In no time flat, you have made the necessary changes and within seconds, the island buzzes to life, powered by solar panels you have only now noticed. You happily board the airship, which is now humming comfortably with machine programmed confidence, and set the controls for the heart of the sun.
Coppice Halifax.credits:
released July 12, 2014
            
            W/P by Brian Grainger. Recorded at Botany Bay, Summer 2014. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. This is Milieu Music number RX19, and 19th in the Static Pharming series.

Coppice Halifax.title: Photo Fluor
Coppice Halifax.about: You're lying down in a green wood, while streams flow down and around you on all sides. At first their burbling waters appear to be clear, then vaguely prismatic - like blowing bubbles - until you begin to realize that they are not water at all, but impossibly endless lines of cassette tape ribbon, reflecting all manner of silver and white from the sunny bright sky above you. Or is it below you? Is this a meadow at all? It starts to feel more like a warm carpet, actually, and that bright sunshine is just a ceiling lamp. Coming back to reality you begin to understand the full effect of your sleep deprivation: a wooden table nearby is filled with several small machines covered in blinking lights, and a black speaker below them belts out a hypnotic rhythm. Beside the machines is a reel to reel which has somehow gone wildly off track, steadily unspooling tape for however long you've been out of it. Maybe twenty minutes? You can't find a clock anywhere, but the reel is nearly exhausted. You pick up the box the reel must've been in - Haddaway's single for "What Is Love?". Man, weird night.
Coppice Halifax.credits:
released April 1, 2014
            
            W/P by Brian Grainger. Recorded at Botany Bay, March 2014. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. This is Milieu Music number RX16, and 16th in the ongoing Static Pharming series.

Coppice Halifax.title: Static Pharming: Year One
Coppice Halifax.about:
Bookending a year very full with Halifaxian works is this five-disc volume of Static Pharming, containing all 12 EPs created throughout 2013, as well as a special new album - Aeriformic Forests - recorded during the Pharming sessions and given a rightful place here. Static Pharming was intended initially to be a single-year series, however the series is now continuing on for a second year in 2014, after I made the realization that things were just starting to become self-aware, conceptually and aurally. From the icy peaks of pieces like "Empty" and the rainslick metallics of "Natow" to the blue skies of "Enhasa" and the deep blue oceans of "D.Y.B.", Static Pharming has transmuted thought to function, function to form in an ever-mutating process of live improvisation, spur of the moment drum programming and rigorous FX saturation, yielding music that is equal parts drone, dub techno and textural ambient. All the hallmarks of the CH sound are clear and accounted for, and the thick woods of Verdant Acre can still be seen from the Static shore. The composting, excavation and Analog Botany alchemy will hereafter continue to expand and explore, but for now, this pillar marks a 12-month descent through nitrous oxide clouds and sedate waters, collected conveniently in one place for the adventurous listener.



"He must go on - conquest beyond conquest. This little planet and its winds and ways, and all the laws of mind and matter that restrain him. Then the planets about him, and at last out across immensity to the stars. And when he has conquered all the deeps of space and all the mysteries of time - still he will be beginning..."



- O. Cabal, 2036
Coppice Halifax.credits:
released December 30, 2013
            
            W/P by Coppice Halifax. Recorded at Botany Bay, January-December 2013. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. This is Milieu Music number RX78.

Coppice Halifax.title: Marine Halide
Coppice Halifax.about:
September brings cooler air and shorter days, a welcome respite from the oppressive heat of each Carolinian sub-tropical summer. Appropriately, the ninth RX of the year is a cool, dusky sweep of burnt leaves and deep golden hues of setting sunlight, all carried fragrantly along on a light breeze that curves in the purple air like invisible poetry. A wondrous calm surrounds the listener with gently bubbling hi hats and AM radio fizzed chord stabs, while the last remnant of a house bassline repeats lazily in a lock-groove. 



"Will the wind ever remember the names it has blown in the past?"

-J.A. Hendrix, 1967
Coppice Halifax.credits:
released September 14, 2014
            
            W/P by Brian Grainger. Recorded September 2014 at Botany Bay. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. This is Milieu Music number RX21, and 21st in the Static Pharming series.

Coppice Halifax.title: [RXØ 25]
Coppice Halifax.about: PHARMLANDS is a set of twelve CH live cuts, each nearly a half-hour in length, that revisit the STATIC PHARMING series by way of transfiguring source synthesis from the fourth year of my WORKINGMAN'S DRONE series alongside a bass monosynth, a couple drum machines and a slew of analog/digital FX processing. Rather than release them all at once, I've decided to issue one cut each day for the twelve days leading up to my 15th wedding anniversary, if for no other reason than personal celebration and reflection. On December 16th, there may or may not be something special and extra released - we'll just have to wait and see, won't we? December is a crazy time, the last crazy month of a crazy year. For now, rest easy and enjoy a classic Halifaxian palette that hasn't been in use for several years now.
Coppice Halifax.credits:
released December 5, 2019
                        
                    
                

                W/P by Brian Grainger. Recorded live at White Pillar Workshop, January 2019. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. This is Milieu Music number RXØ25. Text and design by ABM&D.  www.milieu-music.com  /  www.analogbotany.com



 Special thanks to all of the members of the Milieu Music Fan Club at Patreon  (www.patreon.com/analogbotany).  With their continued support, more music like this release can happen! Coppice Halifax.title: Pol Secondo
Coppice Halifax.about: Starting off with an insistent kick drum pulse, while a slow curtain of white noise and buried symphonics are unveiled inside a reverb tank. Bits of human voices are audible in the fray, and it occurs that this could be what it sounds like inside a womb. The rhythm marches on, and the submerged orchestra coagulates further, assembling a swirling purple storm that surrounds. Dark browns, blues and black become so dense that barely any light touches anything, eventually allowing for the droning monolithic sound to overtake everything.
Coppice Halifax.credits:
released August 3, 2014
            
            W/P by Brian Grainger. Recorded at Botany Bay, Summer 2014. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. This is Milieu Music number RX20, and 20th in the Static Pharming series.

Coppice Halifax.title: Into Fog
Coppice Halifax.about:
"As I wend to the shores I know not,

As I list to the dirge, the voices of men and women wreck’d,

As I inhale the impalpable breezes that set in upon me,

As the ocean so mysterious rolls toward me closer and closer,

I too but signify at the utmost a little wash’d-up drift,

A few sands and dead leaves to gather,

Gather, and merge myself as part of the sands and drift."



-W. Whitman, 1892



For the next-to-last Static Pharming release of the year, RX23 exhibits a slow but steady descent into deeper waters. Opening with crackling texture from a waterlogged ship radio and the far off horn fanfare of a lost vessel's maiden voyage, "Into Fog" coalesces from vapors and humidity into a stately dub techno missive. This ship has traversed several strange seas throughout the year, and what you are hearing here is the sound of being unable to turn back. We're lost for good. All that remains is the vague hope that we will find someone or something familiar inside the fog. Light the lantern, turn down the sails and venture forth once again...
Coppice Halifax.credits:
released November 11, 2014
            
            W/P by Brian Grainger. Recorded at Botany Bay, Autumn 2014. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. This is Milieu Music number RX23 and 23rd in the Static Pharming series.

Coppice Halifax.title: Sift
Coppice Halifax.about:
Sift is October's installment of the Static Pharming series, conjuring up synaesthetic swells of color and texture like gem-glittered dust from the boots of giants. Drawing itself in closely to your ears with big soft sails full of cool wind, Sift gradually reveals a waterlogged rhythm bobbing in and out and around the stereo field, marked occasionally by an echoing woodblock. A single note of extremely muddy bass crawls up to be felt, and the swelling chords of the sunken orchestra become more and more prominent. The whole vessel undulates for several minutes before fading away in a mistlike echo of its actual shape. 



"We'll walk in ecstasy. Clear planet blue and green."

-B. Fiftytwos, 1989
Coppice Halifax.credits:
released October 10, 2014
            
            W/P by Brian Grainger. Recorded at Botany Bay, October 2014. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. This is Milieu Music number RX22, and 22nd in the ongoing Static Pharming series.

Coppice Halifax.title: Static Farm
Coppice Halifax.about:
"I end not far from my going forth

By picking the faded blue

Of the last remaining aster flower

To carry again to you."



-R. Frost, 1915



The end of a two-year road. Static Farm is not a pinnacle, nor a waypoint - rather, a demonstration of movement. A proof of concept that is able to stand on twenty-three other individual experiences. So you'll find that Static Pharming ends where it began - deep techno forms carved out of gaseous audio impressionistically, with the emphasis on lack of emphasis...a detailed meditation on the lack of detail. Hazy, out of focus and designed to induce altered states via repetition, low frequencies and swirling white noise. The Halifaxian vessel floats on, forward into the unknown. Further, into DEEP EARTH...
Coppice Halifax.credits:
released December 16, 2014
            
            W/P by Brian Grainger. Recorded at Botany Bay, November 2014. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. This is Milieu Music number RX24, and 24th in the Static Pharming series.

Coppice Halifax.title: [RXØ 26]
Coppice Halifax.about: PHARMLANDS is a set of twelve CH live cuts, each nearly a half-hour in length, that revisit the STATIC PHARMING series by way of transfiguring source synthesis from the fourth year of my WORKINGMAN'S DRONE series alongside a bass monosynth, a couple drum machines and a slew of analog/digital FX processing. Rather than release them all at once, I've decided to issue one cut each day for the twelve days leading up to my 15th wedding anniversary, if for no other reason than personal celebration and reflection. On December 16th, there may or may not be something special and extra released - we'll just have to wait and see, won't we? December is a crazy time, the last crazy month of a crazy year. For now, rest easy and enjoy a classic Halifaxian palette that hasn't been in use for several years now.
Coppice Halifax.credits:
released December 6, 2019

Coppice Halifax.title: Static Pharming: Year Two
Coppice Halifax.about:
Almost 5 hours of Static Pharming sessions compiled from the 2014 series. All twelve EPs (RX13-24) plus the RX18 overgrowth Lowlights as a bonus 5th album. Deep, impressionist ambient techno, organic drones and loop composting, and various shades of textural dub and spaced-out house music all coalesce into a hazy foggy landscape for you to get lost in. 



Packaged in the same 5xCD black VHS-style case that Static Pharming: Year One was released in, making it the perfect complement to the Halifaxian section of your record shelf.
Coppice Halifax.credits:
released January 11, 2015
            
            W/P by Brian Grainger. Recorded at Botany Bay, January-December 2014. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. This is Milieu Music number RX222.

Coppice Halifax.title: Verdant Acre [Volume One]
Coppice Halifax.about:
Verdant Acre is a massive new project by Coppice Halifax, conceived in Autumn 2011 with initial recording sessions commencing in November 2011. Heavily inspired by the deep ambient techno forests of GAS, the emotive washes of sadness in Yagya, the textural playgrounds of early Vladislav Delay and the brilliant detritus of The Caretaker, Verdant Acre spans a projected six or seven volumes of music, each to be released individually over the coming months. Recorded and assembled using only two drum machines, a mixer, FX devices and damaged orchestral vinyl, the music of Verdant Acre is wild, overgrown and unfamiliar, mirroring much of the dense swamp and marsh lands that Brian grew up exploring as a young man. The songs ooze green mutated growth, earthy darkness and muddy humid atmospheres, where recognizable melodies become tangled and dissonant like vines sprawling up an oak tree, and submerged womblike rhythms provide the only anchor in the abyss. Ideal listening for varying levels of consciousness.



This is volume one in the Verdant Acre series. Volume two will follow in March.
Coppice Halifax.credits:
released February 15, 2012
            
            W/P by Brian Grainger. Recorded at Botany Bay, November 2011-January 2012. This is Milieu Music number VA1.

Coppice Halifax.title: Verdant Versions
Coppice Halifax.about:
Now that the sixth of six volumes have been issued, and the long-running Verdant Acre series is over (or is it?), it only made sense to fashion a collector's box with which to contain the complete set. The Verdant Acre box set is a recycled cardboard box measuring 6x5x1 inches, bearing green text decals, hand numbering and six photographs of mutated Verdant landscapes. It contains all six volumes of the series, unabridged and repackaged in a new design that lends more cohesion with the box itself, making this assemblage both a nice looking item for your record shelf as well as a massive amount of essential Coppice Halifax listening. Totaling 37 tracks spread across seven discs, with a runtime of nearly eight hours, the Verdant Acre box set is packed to the brim with dense ambient techno from the humid heart of South Carolina.



The seventh disc, Verdant Versions, was created with the same concept as Basic Channel's BCD compilation disc in mind - one track selected from each of the six Acre volumes, and presented here in a more dancefloor-friendly iteration. The Versions tracks may bear recognizable resemblance to their originals, however listeners will note several differences...slower or faster tempos, EQ changes, re-mixed layers of sound and even additional bass and percussion elements have been recorded especially for these mutations. Verdant Versions provides yet one more step into the Acre, and accurately sums up many of the series' strongest moments.



As a consideration to the listeners who have already purchased volumes 1 through 6 separately, this box is being made available in two formats: filled with all 6 volumes, plus the Verdant Versions disc, or empty (the box and Verdant Versions only). Only the empty format features Verdant Versions on a black CD-R (like the previously released six volumes), while the filled box's contents have been pressed to standard CD-Rs, making the first editions that much more collectible.
Coppice Halifax.credits:
released August 31, 2012
            
            W/P by Brian Grainger. Recorded at Botany Bay, 2011-2012. This is Milieu Music number VAC.

Coppice Halifax.title: Verdant Overgrowth
Coppice Halifax.about:
A massive conceptual undertaking, Verdant Overgrowth is one of several planned epilogue works for the Verdant Acre six-volume series. After recording sessions for the VA series had finished, I returned to the source tapes and isolated every rhythm track from the original recordings, and adjusted the tempos to match up. Additionally, I isolated the musical elements of the tapes, themselves raw and mutated patches of decayed vinyl detritus and orchestral minor keys, and carefully combined elements from all six volumes to construct an aching eighty-minute ambient atmosphere**. Returning to the rhythm tracks, I assembled a seamless stereo mix containing every rhythm from every track in the six volumes, constantly fading in and out of one another and panning in a circular fashion that is both hypnotic and ever-evolving. Thus, Verdant Overgrowth is an appropriate title for a musical piece that at once sums up around seven hours of recordings and also stands alone as a deep psychedelic ambient techno landscape. 



**This atmosphere will be released in a beatless form at Wil Ru Recordings, bearing the title Verdant Dusk, in the near future.
Coppice Halifax.credits:
released October 11, 2012
            
            W/P by Brian Grainger. Recorded at Botany Bay, Spring-Summer 2012. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. This is Milieu Music number VAØ.

Coppice Halifax.title: Verdant Acre [Volume Two]
Coppice Halifax.about: The second of six volumes in the Verdant Acre series, and a successor to the previous volume in more ways than one. The dense, darkened forestry of the first hour seems to give way to an even deeper and more wildly overgrown part of the Acre. Triumphant horns made of dried leaves and rusted mechanical parts, now overtaken and reclaimed by nature, drone upward into a mute cloudy sky. Hundreds of years of debris uniformly coat the stereo field, each piece an echo of distant and long forgotten lifetimes. This second volume of Verdant Acre is so thick with aural dusts and detritus that it almost feels as if we are hearing the discarded shell of a time that has remained absolutely still for decades, bound by the shape of a world that has truly moved on, and filled with an epoch of longing and sadness. Limited edition of only 50 copies on black CD-Rs packaged in recycled cardstock sleeves with matte photo prints.
Coppice Halifax.credits:
released March 25, 2012
            
            W/P by Brian Grainger. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. This is Milieu Music number VA2.

Coppice Halifax.title: Verdant Acre [Volume Five]
Coppice Halifax.about: The fifth section of the Acre picks up exactly where we left off in Verdant Acre volume four. Dense layers of looped vinyl detritus climb like vines wrapping themselves around a static drum phrase. Clicks, crackles and fuzz fill in the empty holes of the rhythm and once more, the Acre is proving to us just how alive and wild it really is. A fog approaches, carrying the familiar drowned horns of the darker, murkier parts of the Acre. The sun is setting on us and it slowly occurs to us that we are completely lost in the forest...and yet, the black earthy rhythm plods forward into the steadily burnt up evening. Reverb trails coat all we see and hear (and feel) with the glossy dew that will no doubt be visible in the morning. We frantically locate a dry canopy that feels isolated and safe enough, and lay down our bedroll to get some sleep. As we drift off, stolen away by night's silent armies, we smell the soft and salty perfume of the sea, and somehow, we can hear the waves too. Perhaps tomorrow's expedition will reveal the blue horizon line we so long to see...
Coppice Halifax.credits:
released June 20, 2012
            
            W/P by Brian Grainger. Recorded at Botany Bay, Winter-Spring 2012. This is Milieu Music number VA5.

Coppice Halifax.title: Verdant Acre [Volume Four]
Coppice Halifax.about: The fourth volume of the ever-expanding Verdant Acre series is perhaps the most accessible of the set thus far. Building atmospheres from a provenance of melodic and droning loops rather than composted chunks of earthy orchestra, and yielding a crop of six pieces that endlessly bounce and sway like treetops in a heavy wind. There's some cloud cover overhead, but it only takes a few steps forward and a couple deep inhaling breaths to realize the sun is creeping through and slowly brightening the entire landscape. What follows is slowly unveiled, like a massive translucent green curtain over your mind. Grandiose scenes of pastoral nostalgia and electronic summertime fantasies. The sunken orchestras beneath the forest floor have never been closer, their long detuned strings and cracked bows jutting up and out of the grass and mud like defiant threads of petrified wood, reaching for heaven in a long dying breath.
Coppice Halifax.credits:
released May 17, 2012
            
            W/P by Brian Grainger. Recorded at Botany Bay, Winter-Spring 2012. This is Milieu Music number VA4.

Coppice Halifax.title: Verdant Acre [Complete Box Set]
Coppice Halifax.about:
Verdant Acre's mass is equaled only by it's depth. Recorded throughout Autumn and Winter of 2011 and early Spring 2012, and released one volume per month over six months, with Verdant Versions and Verdant Overgrowth following as appendices. The music contained herein is the closest CH has probably ever come to creating music that is a realistic analog of nature - beauty and color buried beneath texture and noise, moments of blissful harmony that sink and waver beneath dissonant winds. The sound of time passing and seasons changing. At once, Verdant Acre is incredibly specific and totally universal.



Taking (perhaps obvious) cues from influences like Wolfgang Voigt's GAS project, early Vladislav Delay, The Caretaker, Andrew Deutsch, Pole and Variant, this series continues to stand tall like the proverbial forest it is, even as the Halifaxian acres expand and run wild around it. This box set attempts to collect all six volumes, as well as Verdant Versions - a dancefloor-friendlier set of edits of one track from each of the six volumes - and Verdant Overgrowth, an 80-minute winding excursion of overlapping loops and rhythms blended together in a seamless pulse of hypnotic repetitions. This is the first time these eight volumes have been collected together in one place, and also the first time the Verdant Acre material has been on a physical format since going out of print sometime in 2013. 



Additionally, two further box sets of Verdant tangents are being issued:  



coppicehalifax.bandcamp.com/album/verdant-compost



  coppicehalifax.bandcamp.com/album/verdant-night



 As well as the following ambient satellite piece: 



coppicehalifax.bandcamp.com/album/verdant-dusk
Coppice Halifax.credits:
released December 10, 2012
            
            W/P by Brian Grainger. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. Recorded at Botany Bay, 2011-2012. Photography and design by Brian Grainger. This is Milieu Music number VA-CB.

Coppice Halifax.title: Verdant Night
Coppice Halifax.about:
Verdant Night is a (not entirely unexpected) beatless extension of the Verdant Acre series, created across several years of alchemical transmutation while the much more rhythmic Verdant Compost project ran parallel alongside its development. Verdant Night reduces each of the six volumes of Verdant Acre into a 60+ minute suite of texture, drones, humid atmospheres and sprawling generative sound. Built using only the original damaged vinyl sides which seeded the entire VA series, alongside an exhaustive studio rig of both analog and digital FX devices, reel to reel and cassette tapes and elaborate generational processing, in order to truly melt down the provenance of Verdant Acre and use it to germinate an entirely new overgrowth of dark green. 



Edited mixes of the six Verdant Night pieces are currently in progress in the White Pillar Workshop, which will complete the cyclical nature of the recordings by rejoining the ambient reductions with the original drum machines used, hopefully yielding a unique drone-techno reincarnation of this endless green sound. Additionally, the original ambient piece that inspired the creation of these six, Verdant Dusk, will appear as a "satellite" release to coincide with the Verdant series revival.
Coppice Halifax.credits:
released May 12, 2017
            
            W/P by Brian Grainger. Recorded at Botany Bay & White Pillar Workshop, 2014-2017. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. This is Milieu Music number VN-B2.

Coppice Halifax.title: Verdant Compost
Coppice Halifax.about:
Almost seven years in gestation, Verdant Compost is finally ready to enter the public consciousness on Earth Day, 2017. A mammoth undertaking larger than any previous remix projects I've attempted before, Verdant Compost collects six discs of reconstituted Verdant Acre source sound, produced by a long and talented list of craftsmen from all over the world. 



The first four discs are sequenced sets of mixes, and the final two are themselves full-length album affairs by Zwei Kreise and Orson Throb, respectively. From deep and dubbed out techno to thick, textured drones, and everywhere in between, Verdant Compost casts a wide range of colors, temperatures and atmospheres, all built using source recordings from the same damaged vinyl sides and drum machines I used to create the original six volumes of the Verdant Acre series. I owe a huge debt of gratitude to the many talented musicians who took part, in order of appearance:

 The box set comes with six special glossy 4x6" photographic prints, mutated and reconfigured from the original Verdant Acre photography, housed comfortably with the six discs inside a VHS-tape sized black plastic box that matches the recent Verdant Acre reinstatement and the ambient companion Verdant Night. 



A humble and grateful thanks to all of the amazing producers who took part in this gigantic project - without you, we may have never known these half-familiar sound fields.

Coppice Halifax.title: Verdant Acre [Volume Three]
Coppice Halifax.about: Further into the Acre we travel, with volume three of Verdant Acre arriving right on time in April. A vibrant Spring season filled with lapping streams, gentle sunshowers, the soft breath of green leaves and fields of blooming flowers. This third section of Verdant Acre is a stark contrast to the first two - where they were covered in moss, shade and black soils, this is a very warm and comfortable place, bright with yellow sunshine, inviting, fragrant. Sweeping chords of archaic wooden instruments bend down into the colorful tangles and shoot back up into the clouds. Percussions as simple as water burbling over rocks stir amongst the crackling-vinyl birdsong. Subtle threads of dissonance phase in and out of the pastoral harmonies, a reminder of the asymmetry and wild untamed overgrowths of nature undisturbed.
Coppice Halifax.credits:
released April 28, 2012
            
            W/P by Brian Grainger. Recorded at Botany Bay, 2011-2012. This is Milieu Music number VA3.

Coppice Halifax.title: Pink Acre
Coppice Halifax.about: At long last, after a year and a half of work, the follow-up to Milkwhite Plastic Galaxy Maker has arrived! Pink Acre is the first of two scheduled cassettes containing the most melodic and playful Coppice Halifax trax in years. Nestled in bedroom warmth and backyard field recordings, filled with echoing moments of adventuring with my daughter, Pink Acre bounds through green grass and crashes into honeysuckles, before curling up on a worn out sofa for a nap in a sunbeam. The music on this release and the Acre that will soon follow is for my daughter Penelope, to assist in her frequent jaunts of toybox carpet fantasies and her humming snoozes in the backseat of my car. Miniature soundtracks for roaming, dreaming, bouncing and brainstorming.
Coppice Halifax.credits:
released February 3, 2017
            
            W/P by Brian Grainger. Recorded at Botany Bay & White Pillar Workshop, 2015-2017. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. This is Recycled Plastics number RPC2-A.

Coppice Halifax.title: Radians
Coppice Halifax.about:
Radians is an album by Coppice Halifax that has undergone many iterations and transformations since its original recording sessions were completed in 2011. Somewhat ironically, these transformed versions of Radians (Reflector on Entropy Records, Hallex and Red Sand at Contemporary Vision) have all been released before Radians itself - this was partially due to the nature of the project (differences in label release schedules, waiting on remixes to be completed, and so on) but in some way it has worked in the album's favor by way of referencing something that does not yet exist, creating a sort of mythology about it. 



Musically, Radians is four original pieces of organic Halifaxian techno, mutated and overgrown in the usual fashion. Meticulously decorated with textures, noises and all manner of analog depth, while still sporting vibrant rhythmic structures, dubby basslines, paint-spatter chords and tape-saturated drones, these four works fit well alongside other CH albums such as Narcotic Months and Dusk Versions. Complementing the originals are four remixes - presented in an inverted sequence so that the album unfolds itself in a reverse motion - by Ohrwert, Contemporary Vision, Emi Ono and a particularly deep rework of Melipal by Coppice Halifax. So the symmetry of Radians is complete, with a full eighty-minute album packed tightly onto a CD-R, and packaged minimally in a black cardboard jacket with stickers.
Coppice Halifax.credits:
released December 21, 2012
            
            Written and produced by Brian Grainger - Except #5: Written by Brian Grainger / Produced & Remixed by Contemporary Vision, #7: Written by Brian Grainger / Produced & Remixed by Ohrwert, #8: Written by Brian Grainger / Produced & Remixed by Emi Ono. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. Tracks #1-4 recorded at Botany Bay, 2011, track #6 rebuilt at Botany Bay, Summer 2012. This is Recycled Plastics number RP4.

Coppice Halifax.title: Verdant Dusk
Coppice Halifax.about:
Drafted in Spring-Summer of 2012, as an ambient reduction of all six sides of the Verdant Acre vinyl source combined, and intended to be cast as a tonal backdrop for the shifting endless rhythms of Verdant Overgrowth. Initially kept isolated only for personal home listening, I was persuaded to release this by close friend/collaborator/confidante Eric Adrian Lee, as a part of an as-yet-unnamed catalog of minimalistic ambient music at his WR label in Portland. 



Like many things, and with many artists, time goes by, and after a couple years Verdant Dusk settled into a darkened corner of my studio's storage, along with untold hours of other unfinished or unreleased things. Only now, in 2017, with the recent crop of Verdant Acre reissues and expansions, will Verdant Dusk have its moment. 



Musically, Verdant Dusk applies a method of working and thinking that is not otherwise present on the Verdant Acre volumes, in that it exists solely in a mode of support, and was created without any notion of rhythm or even musicality. It is the sonic equivalent of a smear of purples and blues along a horizon line, as the clouds give way to a darker background, the color of nightfall. 



This isolated notion of the Verdant Acre vinyl source being transmuted into fully beatless atmosphere was one I could not repress, after a few years of playing Verdant Dusk at night while I passed out reading, and so recording work resumed sometime in 2015 on a much larger effort. The fruits of those efforts became Verdant Night, issued concurrently with Verdant Dusk, as a sort of micro/macro-cosmic statement on the fluidity of time, and how meaningless time itself ultimately is outside of man-made systems. In nature, sounds exist in space. Time pulses out of focus. Night, unending.
Coppice Halifax.credits:
released May 11, 2017
            
            W/P by Brian Grainger. Recorded at Botany Bay, Spring-Summer 2012. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. Photography by Brian, Dayton, 2016. This is Milieu Music number VN-B1.

Coppice Halifax.title: Dusk Versions
Coppice Halifax.about: As a final sendoff for the 2011 year, the appropriately titled Dusk Versions appears as RP2 at Recycled Plastics. Recorded during the same time as the material for both Outward Residence and Parallel Harbors (at Other Heights, Belgium), but much softer and more catered to night time listening. Quiet, restrained rhythms bounce and sway in the background of a dark sonic ether, fogged by the repetitive layers of smoky chords and short melodic stabs punctuating the groove. Variations and refractions of delays twinkle and bubble like living sparks that decorate corners of the room too dark to see. Minimal notes of bass anchor the tracks with submarine propulsion, and sheets of translucent tape warmth and analog reverb are laid gently over the whole structure. This album is an exercise in finality, in closure. The end of another year, and the last appearance of the oft revisited track Dusk, with the minor exception of a remix album due out in 2012 at Other Heights, featuring Quantec, Grad_U, Ohrwert, Axs, Zzzzra and Textural Being.
Coppice Halifax.credits:
released December 16, 2011
            
            W/P by Coppice Halifax. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. Recorded at 114RKD, Spring-Summer 2010. This is Recycled Plastics number RP2.

Plastic Acre is the second of two scheduled cassettes containing the most melodic and playful Coppice Halifax trax in years. Nestled in bedroom warmth and backyard field recordings, filled with echoing moments of adventuring with my daughter, Plastic Acre bounds through green grass and crashes into honeysuckles, before curling up on a worn out sofa for a nap in a sunbeam. The music on this release and the previous Acre is for my daughter Penelope, to assist in her frequent jaunts of toybox carpet fantasies and her humming snoozes in the backseat of my car. Coppice Halifax.title: Milkwhite Plastic Galaxy Maker
Coppice Halifax.about: When Coppice Halifax was first established as a peripheral project of Milieu in 2006, I never would've thought that the two different concepts would connect and overlap in the ways that they have since then. Albums like High Hawaiian Fog, Bedroom Carpet and now this one - they have all walked a very thin line between the CH sound and the Milieu sound. Milkwhite is in some ways a Halifaxian answer to a Milieu album like H Is For Hologram - all the same elements are present: classic drum machines, analog tape recording and an emphasis on a kind of "pure" bedroom electronic music. Where Hologram is more science-fiction, Milkwhite is fantasy, if that analogy makes any sense at all. I began work on this album years ago (sometime in 2010 I think) as nothing more than music for me to play at night while I passed out in bed reading a paperback. Hopefully, that aesthetic of intimate home-space music is still present in the final tracks (which themselves have been retooled and tightened up in spots, as reflected on the precursor release Sno Dreem). In short, Milkwhite is a playful set of feel-good bedroom braindance, sure to please appreciators of both the Milieu and Coppice Halifax varieties.
Coppice Halifax.credits:
released April 28, 2012
            
            W/P by Brian Grainger. Recorded at 114RKD, 2010. This is Recycled Plastics number RP3.

Coppice Halifax.title: Vaporized Forest Index
Coppice Halifax.about:
Coppice Halifax, originally a Milieu side-project, has now aged a decade. After a full year of painstaking selection, editing, sequencing and mastering, VAPORIZED FOREST INDEX is finally complete. A beginner's guide to the dense subtropical forests and the sprawling Atlantic seaside. Writing and assembling this collection has felt surreal and almost predetermined, as the track selection ended up numbering 33, while I am in my 33rd year. Three discs, as well - themselves grouped according to the general peaks and valleys of the Halifaxian oeuvre - spanning four hours of material from 2006 to 2016.



The first Cide, subtitled CARPET, contains fourteen tracks that orbit the earlier Coppice Halifax core of melodic techno. These are tracks inspired by Warp's Artificial Intelligence series, early Rephlex vinyl like Cylobian Sunset, Desktop Robotics and Wasted Sunday, as well as early RDJ like SAW 85-92 and Surfing On Sine Waves. These are the pieces that most easily blur the lines between Milieu and CH, and establish a provenance that spirals further outward into deeper and more textured acres. 



The second Cide, subtitled CONTOUR, highlights the dub techno phase of CH, with tracks from the Analog Botany and Static Pharming series, Ocean Lion and Pawleys Island. This material is mostly inspired by Rod Modell's early Deepchord vinyl, labels like Chain Reaction, Mille Plateaux and early Kompakt, such as Dettinger or Jonas Bering. These pieces maintain a balance of techno rhythms and warm minimalistic basslines, anchored below layer upon layer of humid chords and restrained melodies - the sum of which often floats in a shallow pool of field recordings and tape hiss. 



The third and final Cide, subtitled COMPOST, contains the summation of those years lost in the Halifaxian overgrowth. Heavily textured works filled with mammoth drones, orchestral tape loops, guitar feedback walls, modular synthesizer constructs and a truly Impressionistic presentation of ambient music, deep techno and bedroom experimentalism. These pieces have been inspired by GAS, Aleksi Perala's Colundi series, Ourson's Warming Plant album, Mika Vainio's Ø alias, early Vladislav Delay recordings and Steve Hitchell's sprawling Variant, Echospace and cv313 projects. 



As a whole, these 33 tracks present a cohesive and guided trip through the Halifaxian ten year acre, while also hopefully providing a carefully considered tableaux of works for even the most ardent listener to appreciate. Where Milieu has always been a far more deliberate and composed project, Coppice Halifax eschews traditional forms of songwriting in favor of sonic mining and map making. Compost as composition, synthesis as song. 



For most of these past ten years, I've not been the creator of these woods and oceans - only a cultivator of analog botany, riding a wave thick with seratonin and surrealism. I've never been a builder, but a draftsman, providing the means for possible realities to enter into existence. Like Michaelangelo digging out the statue from inside the stone, and Monet repainting the Rouen Cathedral dozens of times in different grades of sunlight, I have accepted that there are greater forms in the universe than those I can conjure on my own, and they are far richer things to excavate and frame with so many miles of rippling cassette tape. Shapes in the vapour, phosphenes in the darkness, vibrations and radio frequencies in dimly lit machines, nudged to and fro by a sleep-deprived hand.
Coppice Halifax.credits:
released December 16, 2016
            
            W/P by Brian Grainger. Recorded at Rolling Knoll and Botany Bay, 2006-2016, in beautiful South Carolina. Mastered by The Analog Botanist at White Pillar Workshop, Autumn 2016. Photo taken by Brian in Columbia, SC, Spring 2016. This is Recycled Plastics number RPCHX. (C) + (P) Coppice Halifax 2016. All rights reserved.

Coppice Halifax.title: Ice Forest
Coppice Halifax.about:
Happy holidays from Coppice Halifax!



A Halifaxian interpretation of the cold ending of the year, and something to smear your brain across while the temperatures drop. Produced in the older style of Coppice Halifax records, with full compressor abuse to the point of textural overload, and inspired in equal parts by drone-techno fellows Submersion and Mon0, and the transmutation of the cold itself into sonic tapestry. 



The limited edition CD-R version contains the bonus 40+ minute piece "Ice Forest [Melted]", to warm your insides back up after traversing the immense and formidable Ice Forest. This version on the Coppice Halifax Bandcamp page also features alternative cover art to the RP release, although both cover files come included in the download - use whichever one you prefer!
Coppice Halifax.credits:
released December 1, 2014
            
            W/P by Brian Grainger. Recorded at Botany Bay, November 2014. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. This is Recycled Plastics number BC31, and 31st in the ongoing Bedroom Compost series.

Coppice Halifax.title: White Pillar IV
Coppice Halifax.about:
White Pillar IV is the fourth of a multi-part series, intended to both document and transfigure the sonic ephemera from the White Pillar Workshop's surrounding area - a valley in southern Ohio, near such things as a USAF base, NASA and the Serpent Mound, the largest serpent effigy in the world, which dates back to 300 BCE. These locations and several others factor heavily into what populates the airwaves and frequency bands of many types, and the White Pillar series exists to isolate such bands and transmute them into something musically affecting. As such, it is fitting that this recording and those that follow it bear the namesake of the new studio, christening it publicly and properly, and looking ever forward to the future.



This fourth volume was recorded live using a 95% analog rig, including Korg Volca Beats/Bass/Keys, a Nintendo 3DS XL, a BBE Two Timer delay, a Nady MM14-FX delay mixer, the Alesis Quadraverb, a Pioneer spring reverb box and a Peavey FX2 mixing desk.
Coppice Halifax.credits:
released July 3, 2017
            
            W/P by Brian Grainger. Recorded live at White Pillar Workshop, Spring 2017. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. This is Milieu Music number WPW004. Photography by Brian at Rolling Knoll, Summer 2016.

Coppice Halifax.credits:

            W/P by Brian Grainger. Recorded live at White Pillar Workshop, October 2016, using intercepted AM radio signals in conjunction with a Yamaha RY20, Alesis Microbrute and a host of unique analog/digital FX devices. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. Photography by Brian at Rolling Knoll, Summer 2016. This is Milieu Music number WPW001.

Coppice Halifax.title: White Pillar [Recalled]
Coppice Halifax.about: While looking through old hard drives and SD cards for a specific field recording, I stumbled upon three lost tracks from the very first White Pillar session, in November 2016. These three tracks were made right after the extended jam that became White Pillar 1, and feature the same gear configuration surfing across AM radio waves, zeroing in on interesting overtones and melodic transients. Vaguely remembered, and thought lost until now, they cohesively explore a liminal space between the White Pillar series and something more austere and experimental, such as Deep Earth. Huge sub bass collides with snappy percussive chunks, while fuzz-scrambled speech and pop music seeps through the radio bands like radiation. Surreal and unique techno for close listening as well as larger speaker systems.
Coppice Halifax.credits:
released May 17, 2018
            
            W/P by Brian Grainger. Recorded live November 2016 at White Pillar Workshop, using intercepted AM radio signals in conjunction with a Yamaha RY20, Arturia Microbrute and a host of unique analog/digital FX devices. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. Photography by Brian, Dayton 2018. This is Milieu Music number WPW000, a precursor to the White Pillar series.



Special thanks to all of the members of the Milieu Music Fan Club at Patreon  (www.patreon.com/analogbotany).  With their continued support, more music like this release can happen! At the present moment, the members of the Fan Club are: Justin T, Burton T, William C, Brian C, Chris S, Levi G, Rich A, Jonathan W, Joel B, Matthew D, Peter B, Rik J, Jose S, Tony S, Alex G, Seth B, Jim P, David T, Devin H, Mathieu L, Andy B, Francois H, Benoit P, Daniel F, Gordon C, Alex K, Peter B, Sean W, Alex B.

Coppice Halifax.title: White Pillar V
Coppice Halifax.about:
White Pillar V is the fifth of a multi-part series, intended to both document and transfigure the sonic ephemera from the White Pillar Workshop's surrounding area - a valley in southern Ohio, near such things as a USAF base, NASA and the Serpent Mound, the largest serpent effigy in the world, which dates back to 300 BCE. These locations and several others factor heavily into what populates the airwaves and frequency bands of many types, and the White Pillar series exists to isolate such bands and transmute them into something musically affecting. As such, it is fitting that this recording and those that follow it bear the namesake of the new studio, christening it publicly and properly, and looking ever forward to the future.



This fifth volume was recorded live using a 95% analog rig, including Korg Volca Beats/Bass/Keys, a BBE Two Timer delay, a Nady MM14-FX delay mixer, the Alesis Quadraverb, a Pioneer spring reverb box and a Peavey FX2 mixing desk.

released July 4, 2017
            
            W/P by Brian Grainger. Recorded live at White Pillar Workshop, Spring 2017. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. This is Milieu Music number WPW005. Photography by Brian at Rolling Knoll, Summer 2016.
